d and t , as does m to b and p , and ng to g and k. This sound, namely, implies for its formation the same check or mute-contact as d and t , with sonant vibration of the vocal cords as in d , and further with unclosure of the passage from the mouth into the nose, and nasal resonance there. Among the nasals, it is by far the most common in English pronunciation (more than twice as common as m , and eight times as common as ng ). While all the nasals are semivocalic or liquid, n is the only one which (like l , but not more than half as often) is used with vocalic value in syllable-making: namely, in unaccented syllables, where an accompanying vowel, formerly uttered, is now silenced: examples are token, rotten, open, lesson, reason, oven; such form, on an average, about one in eight hundred of English syllables. The sign n has no variety of sounds; but before ch, j , in the same syllable (as in inch, hinge ) it takes on a slightly modified—a palatalized—character; and similarly it is gutturalized, or pronounced as ng , before k and g (hard), as in ink, finger; and its digraph ng (see G ) is the usual representative of the guttural or back-palatal nasal, which in none of our alphabets has a letter to itself. N is doubled under the same circumstances as other consonants, and in a few words (as kiln, damn, hymn ) is silent. In the phonetic history of our family of languages, n is on the whole a constant sound; that is to say, there is no other sound into which it passes on a large scale; but its loss, with accompanying vowel-modification, has been a frequent process.

In behalf of; on the part of; by the authority of: used often in invocation, adjuration, or the like: as, it was done in the name of the people; in the name of common sense, what do you mean? in God's name , spare us.
In the capacity or character of.
Compare name of God .

Synonyms Name, Appellation, Title, Designation, Denomination, Style. Name is the simplest and most general word for that by which any person or thing is called: as, “His name is John,” Luke i. 63. An appellation is a descriptive and therefore specific term, as Saint Louis; John's appellation was the Baptist ; George Washington has the appellation of Father of his Country. A title is an official or honorary appellation, as reverend, bishop, doctor, colonel, duke. A designation is a distinctive appellation or title, marking the individual, as Charles the Simple , James the Less. Denomination is to a class what designation is to an individual: as, coin of various denominations ; a common use of the word is in application to a separate or independent Christian body or organization. Style may be essentially the same as appellation , but it is now generally limited to a name assumed or assigned for public use: as, the style of his most Christian Majesty; they transacted business under the firm style of Smith & Co.
Repute, credit, note.

A beautiful youth fabled to have been enamored of his own image as seen in a fountain, and to have been changed into the flower called Narcissus.
Any of several bulbous flowering plants , of the genus Narcissus , having white or yellow cup - or trumpet -shaped flowers, notably the daffodil
A beautiful young man, like the mythological Greek Narcissus
(Greek mythology) a beautiful young man who fell in love with his own reflection
bulbous plant having erect linear leaves and showy yellow or white flowers either solitary or in clusters

narcist.explanation: Someone in love with themselves; a narcissist.

narcoanalysis.explanation: Psychotherapy conducted while the patient is in a sleeplike state induced by barbiturates or other drugs, especially as a means of releasing repressed feelings, thoughts, or memories. Its use is restricted to circumstances where there is a compelling, immediate need for a patient's responses.
A form of psychotherapy in which the patient is administered drugs in order to attain a sleeplike state.

narcohypnosis.explanation: A hypnotic state induced by narcotics .

narcolepsy.explanation: A disorder characterized by sudden and uncontrollable, though often brief, attacks of deep sleep, sometimes accompanied by paralysis and hallucinations.
A condition characterized by a tendency to fall into a short sleep on all occasions.
Petit mal, when presenting a simple brief loss of consciousness.
A disorder characterized by sudden and uncontrollable attacks of deep sleep , often brief , sometimes accompanied by paralysis and hallucinations
a sleep disorder characterized by sudden and uncontrollable episodes of deep sleep

narcomania.explanation: A morbid craving for some narcotic drug.
A pathological craving for or addiction to narcotics or alcohol .

narcomaniac.explanation: A person who suffers from narcomania .

narcosis.explanation: A condition of deep stupor or unconsciousness produced by a drug or other chemical substance.
In pathology , the stupefying effect of a narcotic; narcotism.
Privation of sense or consciousness, due to a narcotic.
Unconsciousness caused by a drug , anaesthetic or other chemical substance.
unconsciousness induced by narcotics or anesthesia

narcostimulant.explanation: An agent having combined narcotic and stimulant properties.

narcosynthesis.explanation: Narcoanalysis directed toward making the patient recall repressed memories and emotional traumas.
A form of narcoanalysis in which the patient is made to recall repressed memories under hypnosis .

narcotic.explanation: A drug, such as morphine or heroin, that is derived from opium or an opiumlike compound, relieves pain, often induces sleep, can alter consciousness, and is potentially addictive.
A soothing, numbing agent or thing.
Inducing sleep or stupor; causing narcosis.
Of or relating to narcotics, their effects, or their use.
Of, relating to, or intended for one addicted to a narcotic.
A substance which directly induces sleep, allaying sensibility and blunting the senses, and which, in large quantities, produces narcotism or complete insensibility.
Having the properties of a narcotic; operating as a narcotic.

A drug which, in medicinal doses, generally allays morbid susceptibility, relieves pain, and produces sleep; but which, in poisonous doses, produces stupor, coma, or convulsions, and, when given in sufficient quantity, causes death. The best examples are opium (with morphine), belladonna (with atropine), and conium.
Any class of substances or drugs , that reduces pain , induces sleep and may alter mood or behaviour .
of or relating to or designating narcotics
a drug that produces numbness or stupor; often taken for pleasure or to reduce pain; extensive use can lead to addiction

narcoticalness.explanation: The property of being narcotic, or of operating as a narcotic.

narcotine.explanation: A crystallized alkaloid of opium, C 22 H 23 NO 7 .
An alkaloid found in opium, and extracted as a white crystalline substance, tasteless and less poisonous than morphine; -- called also narcotia .
An alkaloid found in opium ; noscapine

narcotism.explanation: Addiction to narcotics such as opium, heroin, or morphine.
The influence exerted by narcotics, or the effects produced by their use.
Narcosis; the state of being narcotized.
A narcotic effect; the tendency to cause narcosis .

narcotization.explanation: The act or process of narcotizing; the state of being narcotized; narcotic poisoning.
the state of being narcotized ; narcosis
the act of narcotizing someone or something

narcotize.explanation: To place under the influence of a narcotic.
To imbue with, or subject to the influence of, a narcotic; to put into a state of narcosis.
To use a narcotic in order to make someone drowsy or insensible ; to anesthetize .
To make something into a narcotic.

narcotized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of narcotize .

narcotizes.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of narcotize .

narcs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of narc .

nard.explanation: A plant: same as spikenard . See Nardostachys .
An aromatic unguent prepared from this plant.
Same as mat-grass , 2. See also Nardus .
A European plant, Valeriana Celtica , formerly used in medicine; also, one of other species of valerian.
An East Indian plant ( Nardostachys Jatamansi ) of the Valerian family, used from remote ages in Oriental perfumery.
An ointment prepared partly from this plant. See Spikenard .
A kind of grass ( Nardus stricta ) of little value, found in Europe and Asia.

A flowering plant of the Valerian family that grows in the Himalayas of China, used as a perfume, an incense , a sedative , and an herbal medicine said to fight insomnia , flatulence , birth difficulties, and other minor ailments .
A fragrant oil formerly much prized from the plant .
American 1980s slang word for testicles, equivalent to balls or nuts . Example: The soccer ball hit me right in the nards!
an aromatic ointment used in antiquity

nardine.explanation: Of or pertaining to nard; having the qualities of nard.

nardoo.explanation: An Australian plant, Marsilea Drummondii ( M. macropus of Hooker).
An Australian name for Marsilea Drummondii , a four-leaved cryptogamous plant, sometimes used for food.
Marsilea drummondii, a four-leaved cryptogamous plant sometimes used for food .

nardus.explanation: A genus of plants of the order Gramineæ and the tribe Hordeæ , known by the absence of the empty glumes and of the stalklet beyond the flower. There is but one species, See mat-grass , 2.

nare.explanation: A nostril; especially, the nostril of a hawk.
nostril found in the beak of a bird

nares.explanation: The nostrils or nasal openings, -- the anterior nares being the external or proper nostrils, and the posterior nares , the openings of the nasal cavities into the mouth or pharynx.

narghile.explanation: An Eastern tobacco-pipe in which the smoke passes through water before reaching the lips, the water being contained in a receptacle originally of cocoanut, now often of glass, porcelain, or metal. (Compare sheesheh .) The stem is a long flexible tube, often called a snake. See kalian .
A large Oriental tobacco pipe wherein the smoke is drawn through water to filter and cool it.
an oriental tobacco pipe with a long flexible tube connected to a container where the smoke is cooled by passing through water

nargile.explanation: An apparatus for smoking tobacco. It has a long flexible tube, and the smoke is drawn through water. Also called hoookah and water pipe . Functionally similar to the hubble-bubble , a simplified form.

nargileh.explanation: an oriental tobacco pipe with a long flexible tube connected to a container where the smoke is cooled by passing through water

narial.explanation: of, pertaining to, or located at or near, the nares .
of or relating to or near the nares

naricorn.explanation: The horny nasal sheath of the beak of some birds, overlying or incasing the nostrils, as in petrels and albatrosses; the rhinotheca, or nasal case: in some birds, as albatrosses, it is a separate piece.

narine.explanation: Of or belonging to the nostrils.

naris.explanation: An external opening in the nasal cavity of a vertebrate; a nostril.
any of the openings to the nasal cavities that allow air to flow through the cavities to the pharynx

nark.explanation: An informer, especially a police informer.
A law enforcement agent specializing in narcotics law violations.
To serve or behave as a spy or informer.
an informer or spy working for the police
a lawman concerned with narcotics violations
cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations

narked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of nark .

narks.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of nark .

narky.explanation: Irritated , in a bad mood; disparaging .

narra.explanation: In the Philippine Islands, Pterocarpus Indicus and Pterocarpus echinatus , valuable hardwood trees from which furniture is made. See asana , with cut.

narrate.explanation: To give an account of (events, for example) in speech or writing or by means of images. synonym : describe .
To supply a running commentary for (a documentary or performance, for example).
Describe, Narrate (see describe ), detail, recount, repeat.
To tell, rehearse, or recite, as a story; to relate the particulars of; to go through with in detail, as an incident or transaction; to give an account of.
To relate a story or series of events by speech or writing.
narrate or give a detailed account of
provide commentary for a film, for example

narrated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of narrate .

narrater.explanation: one who narrates, tells a story, relates events

narrates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of narrate .

narratio.explanation: In civil law , an account or formal statement in pleading, setting forth the facts constituting the plaintiff's cause of action: used to some extent at common law. Abbreviated narr.

narration.explanation: The act, process, or an instance of narrating.
The art of recounting or relating in order the particulars of some action, occurrence, or affair; a narrating.
That which is narrated or recounted; an orderly recital of the details and particulars of some transaction or event, or of a series of transactions or events; a story or narrative.
Specifically In rhetoric , that part of an oration in which the speaker makes his statement of facts.
Synonyms Account, Relation, Narrative , etc. See account .
The act of telling or relating the particulars of an event; a recital of certain events, usually in chronological order; rehearsal.
That which is related; the relation in words or writing of the particulars of any transaction or event, or of any series of transactions or events; a narrative; story; history.
That part of a discourse which recites the time, manner, or consequences of an action, or simply states the facts connected with the subject.
The act of recounting or relating in order the particulars of some action, occurrence , or affair; a narrating .
That which is narrated or recounted; an orderly recital of the details and particulars of some transaction or event , or of a series of transactions or events; a story or narrative .
That part of an oration in which the speaker makes his or her statement of facts.
the act of giving an account describing incidents or a course of events
(rhetoric) the second section of an oration in which the facts are set forth
a message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program

narrative.explanation: The art, technique, or process of narrating.
The presentation of the positions of a politician or political party in the media, as by press releases, speeches, and interviews.
Consisting of or characterized by the telling of a story.
That which is narrated; a connected account of the particulars of an event or transaction, or series of incidents; a relation or narration; a story.
The art of narrating or recounting in detail: as, he is very skilful in narrative.
Synonyms Account, Relation, Narrative , etc. See account .
Of or pertaining to narration; relating to the particulars of an event or transaction.
Apt or inclined to relate stories, or to tell particulars of events; story-telling; garrulous.
That which is narrated; the recital of a story; a continuous account of the particulars of an event or transaction; a story.
The systematic recitation of an event or series of events.
consisting of or characterized by the telling of a story
a message that tells the particulars of an act or occurrence or course of events; presented in writing or drama or cinema or as a radio or television program

narratively.explanation: In a narrative manner: in the form of a story

narrator.explanation: One who narrates; one who recounts or states facts, details, etc.
In the older oratorios and passions, the personage who sings the historical parts of the text, so as to give the proper setting for the dramatic and lyric numbers.
One who narrates; one who relates a series of events or transactions.
One who narrates or tells stories.
The person or the " voice " whose viewpoint is used in telling a story.
The person providing the voice-over in a documentary .

narratory.explanation: Giving an account of events; narrative.
Relating to a narrator and/or narration .

narrow.explanation: Of small or limited width, especially in comparison with length.
Limited in area or scope; cramped.
Lacking flexibility; rigid.
Barely sufficient; close.
Painstakingly thorough or attentive; meticulous.
Tense.
To reduce in width or extent; make narrower.
To limit or restrict.
To become narrower; contract.
A part of little width, as a pass through mountains.
A body of water with little width that connects two larger bodies of water.
A part of a river or an ocean current that is not wide.
nary .
narrow one's sphere of action.
knitting , to reduce the number of stitches of: opposed to widen: as, to narrow a stocking at the toe.
manège , to take less than the proper ground in stepping, or bear out insufficiently to the one hand or the other: said of a horse.
knitting , to reduce the number of stitches, either by knitting two together or by slipping one and binding it over the next: as, when you reach this point you must narrow.
narrow channel or passage; a narrow ribbon.
narrow fortune.
narrow majority or escape (that is, a majority so small or an escape so close as almost to fail of being a majority or an escape).
and Cramped, pinched, scanty, mean.

A strait; a narrow passage through a mountain, or a narrow channel of water between one sea or lake and another; a sound; any contracted part of a navigable river or harbor: used chiefly in the plural: as, the Narrows at the entrance of New York harbor.
A contracted part of an ocean current: usually in the plural: as, the narrows of the Gulf Stream at the south point of Florida.
plural In coal-mining , roadways or galleries driven at right angles to drifts, and smaller than these in section.
A narrow passage; esp., a contracted part of a stream, lake, or sea; a strait connecting two bodies of water; -- usually in the plural.
To lessen the breadth of; to contract; to draw into a smaller compass; to reduce the width or extent of.
To contract the reach or sphere of; to make less liberal or more selfish; to limit; to confine; to restrict
To contract the size of, as a stocking, by taking two stitches into one.
Of little breadth; not wide or broad; having little distance from side to side
Of little extent; very limited; circumscribed.
Having but a little margin; having barely sufficient space, time, or number, etc.; close; near{5}; -- with special reference to some peril or misfortune
Limited as to means; straitened; pinching.
Contracted; of limited scope; illiberal; bigoted
Parsimonious; niggardly; covetous; selfish.
Scrutinizing in detail; close; accurate; exact.

Formed (as a vowel) by a close position of some part of the tongue in relation to the palate; or (according to Bell) by a tense condition of the pharynx; -- distinguished from wide ; as ē (ēve) and � (f�d), etc., from ĭ (ĭll) and � (f�t), etc. See Guide to Pronunciation , §13.
See Note under Gauge , n., 6.
To become less broad; to contract; to become narrower.
Not to step out enough to the one hand or the other.
To contract the size of a stocking or other knit article, by taking two stitches into one.
having a small width; not wide ; slim ; slender ; having opposite edges or sides that are close , especially by comparison to length or depth .
Restrictive ; without flexibility or latitude .

narrowcast.explanation: To communicate or transmit (a signal, a message, or content, such as audio or video programming) to a specific group of recipients simultaneously over a communication network.
To communicate or transmit a signal, a message, or content, such as audio or video programming, to a specific group of recipients simultaneously over a communication network.
The act or process of narrowcasting a signal, a message, or content, such as audio or video programming.
A signal, message, or audio or video program that is narrowcast over a communication network.
To transmit a programme to selected individuals or groups , especially via cable
A programme transmitted in this manner

narrowed.explanation: reduced in size as if by being squeezed.
Simple past tense and past participle of narrow .
reduced in size as by squeezing together

narrower.explanation: One who or that which narrows or contracts.
One who, or that which, narrows or contracts.
comparative form of narrow : more narrow
One who, or that which, narrows .

narrowest.explanation: superlative form of narrow : most narrow .

narrowing.explanation: In knitting , the act of reducing the breadth of the work, as by throwing two stitches into one.
The part of the work which has been thus narrowed or contracted.
The act of contracting, or of making or becoming less in breadth or extent.
The part of a stocking which is narrowed.
The part of a stocking that is narrowed .
the act of making something narrower

narrowly.explanation: With little breadth; in a narrow manner.

With close adherence to the literal meaning of a text.

in a narrow manner; not allowing for exceptions

narrowness.explanation: The quality or condition of being narrow, in any sense of that word.

a restriction of range or scope
the property of being narrow; having little width
an inclination to criticize opposing opinions or shocking behavior

narrows.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of narrow .
A narrow part of a navigable waterway .

narsarsukite.explanation: A titano-silicate of ferric iron and sodium, occurring in honey-yellow to brownish-gray tabular tetragonal crystals: from the neighborhood of Narsarsuk in Southern Greenland.
A tetragonal-dipyramidal mineral containing fluorine , iron , oxygen , silicon , sodium , and titanium .

narthecium.explanation: A genus of herbs of the order Liliaceæ type of the tribe Narthecieæ , known by its single style, stiff open flowers, and rigid linear loaves in two ranks, rising from a creeping rootstock.
bog asphodels; sometimes placed in family Melanthiaceae

narthex.explanation: A portico or lobby of an early Christian or Byzantine church or basilica, originally separated from the nave by a railing or screen.
An entrance hall leading to the nave of a church.
A western vestibule leading to the nave in some (especially Orthodox) Christian churches.

narwal.explanation: small Arctic whale the male having a long spiral ivory tusk

narwhal.explanation: An Arctic whale (Monodon monoceros) having mottled gray or whitish skin and in the male, a long spirally twisted tusk projecting forward from the left side of the head.
A cetacean, Monodon monoceros , of the family Delphinidræ and the subfamily Delphinapterinæ; the sea-unicorn, unicorn-whale, or unicorn-fish.

An arctic cetacean ( Monodon monocerous ), about twenty feet long. The male usually has one long, twisted, pointed canine tooth, or tusk, projecting forward from the upper jaw like a horn, whence it is called also sea unicorn , unicorn fish , and unicorn whale . Sometimes two horns are developed, side by side.
An Arctic cetacean , about 20 feet (6 meters) long; the male has a single twisted pointed canine tooth or tusk projecting forward like a horn .
small Arctic whale the male having a long spiral ivory tusk

narwhale.explanation: small Arctic whale the male having a long spiral ivory tusk

nary.explanation: ne'er a, never a (the article being sometimes erroneously repeated after the word in which it is contained).
(used with singular count nouns) colloquial for `not a' or `not one' or `never a'

nasal.explanation: Of, in, or relating to the nose.

Articulated by lowering the soft palate so that air resonates in the nasal cavities and passes out the nose, as in the pronunciation of the consonants (m), (n), and (ng) or the nasalized vowel of French bon.
Characterized by or resembling a resonant sound produced through the nose.
A nasal consonant.
A nasal part or bone, forming part of the bridge of the nose.
The nosepiece of a helmet.
entomology , pertaining to the nasus or clypeus.

ornithology , the depressions upon the bill of a bird in which the external nostrils open. These are usually wellmarked fossæ at or near the base of the bill, on either side of the culmen, naked or filled in with feathers, or arched over by an operculum or nasal scale; their characters are often of zoological importance. See cuts and diagram under bill.
, a process of the frontal bone in part supporting the two nasal bones;
, a median process of each maxillary bone, together forming one spine which projects at the base of the outer nostrils or anterior nares;

, a corresponding median process of the conjoined palate-bones in the floor of the posterior nares, at the root of the uvula. The last two processes are sometimes called prenasal and postnasal. The anterior process has some ethnological significance, being best developed in the higher races of men, and is also one of several datum-points in craniometry.
A part of a helmet which protects the nose and adjacent parts of the face. It was made in various forms. Also called nose-piece . See also cut-under helmet.
A sound uttered through or partly through the nose: especially, a nasal mute or stop, as m, n, ng.
In anatomy , one of the nasal bones.
In herpetology , a nasal plate or shield.
Of or pertaining to the nose.

Having a quality imparted by means of the nose; and specifically, made by lowering the soft palate, in some cases with closure of the oral passage, the voice thus issuing (wholly or partially) through the nose, as in the consonants m, n, ng (see Guide to Pronunciation , §§ 20, 208); characterized by resonance in the nasal passage
two bones of the skull, in front of the frontals.

in the skull, the ratio of the transverse breadth of the anterior nasal aperture to the height from the base of the aperture to the nasion, which latter distance is taken as the standard, equal to 100.
An elementary sound which is uttered through the nose, or through both the nose and the mouth simultaneously.
A medicine that operates through the nose; an errhine.
Part of a helmet projecting to protect the nose; a nose guard .
One of the nasal bones.
A plate, or scale, on the nose of a fish, etc.
Of or pertaining to the nose .

Having a quality imparted by means of the nose; and specifically , made by lowering the soft palate , in some cases with closure of the oral passage, the voice thus issuing (wholly or partially) through the nose, as in the consonants m, n, ng; characterized by resonance in the nasal passage ; as, a nasal vowel ; a nasal utterance .
An elementary sound which is uttered through the nose, or through both the nose and the mouth simultaneously , such asm and n.

sounding as if the nose were pinched
of or in or relating to the nose
a consonant produced through the nose with the mouth closed

nasalis.explanation: A muscle on either side of the nose, the action of which is to depress the ala?, narrowing the anterior nares. Also called compressor naris .

A genus of mammals comprising the proboscis monkeys.

nasality.explanation: The state or quality of being nasal.

nascence.explanation: A coming into being; a beginning: synonym : beginning .
Origination; birth; beginning; specifically, in phytogeography , the rise of a new plant formaation on an area destitute of floral covering.

nascency.explanation: State of being nascent; birth; beginning; origin.
A state of incipiency ; a quality of nascence .

nascent.explanation: Commencing, or in process of development; beginning to exist or to grow; coming into being.

the fleeting or momentary state of an uncombined atom or radical just separated from one compound, and not yet united with another, -- a hypothetical condition implying peculiarly active chemical properties.
Of the state of an element at the time it is generated from some compound .

naseberry.explanation: The tree Achras Sapota , or its fruit. See Achras, bully-tree, chicle-gum , and sapodilla.

nasicorn.explanation: A member of the Nasicornia; a rhinoceros or rhinocerotid.

Bearing a horn , or horns, on the nose , as the rhinoceros does.

nassa.explanation: Any species of marine gastropods, of the genera Nassa, Tritia, and other allied genera of the family Nassidæ ; a dog whelk. See Illust. under gastropoda .

nastic.explanation: Of or relating to a movement of a plant that is in response to an external stimulus but is in a direction independent of the direction of the stimulus, as in the diurnal movement of leaves.

nastier.explanation: comparative form of nasty : more nasty

nastiest.explanation: superlative form of nasty : most nasty .

1 and 3. Nasty, Filthy, Foul, Dirty. These words are on the descending scale of strength. Nasty is the strongest word in the language for that which is offensive to sight, smell, or touch by the quality of its uncleanness or uncleanliness, The English fondness for the colloquial use of the word in connection with bad weather, and figuratively for anything disagreeable, is not matched by anything in America; on the contrary, the word is considered too strong for ordinary or delicate use, and foul is used of bad weather. All the words apply to that which is filled or covered in considerable degree with anything offensive. The moral uses of the word correspond with the physical.

Natal, Native, Natural. Natal has the narrow meaning of belonging to the event of one's birth; hence it is chiefly used with such words as day, hour, star. Native means conferred by birth: as, native genius; or, belonging by birth or origiu; as, native place, country, language. Natural applies to that which is by nature, as opposed to the work of art. Native eloquence is opposed to that which is acquired; natural eloquence to that which is elaborated by rules.

Conformity to nature or to reality; a close adherence to nature in the arts of painting, sculpture, poetry, etc.: opposed to idealism , and implying less of crudeness than realism.
Specifically, in the fine arts , the rendering of nature, as it is, by the arts of design, but without either slavish fidelity or attempt at illusion. It is the mean between idealism and realism.
In philosophy , that view of the world, and especially of man and human history and society, which takes account only of natural (as distinguished from supernatural) elements and forces.
In theology :
The doctrine that natural religion is sufficient for salvation.
The doctrine that all religious truth is derived from a study of nature without any supernatural revelation, and that all religious life is a natural development unaided by supernatural influences.
A state of nature; conformity to nature.

The doctrine of those who deny a supernatural agency in the miracles and revelations recorded in the Bible, and in spiritual influences; also, any system of philosophy which refers the phenomena of nature to a blind force or forces acting necessarily or according to fixed laws, excluding origination or direction by one intelligent will.
The theory that art or literature should conform to nature; realism; also, the quality, rendering, or expression of art or literature executed according to this theory.

The principles and characteristics professed or represented by a 19th-century school of realistic writers, notably by Zola and Maupassant, who aimed to give a literal transcription of reality, and laid special stress on the analytic study of character, and on the scientific and experimental nature of their observation of life.
A state of nature; conformity to nature .
Metaphaphoric: The doctrine that denies a supernatural agency in the miracles and revelations recorded in the Bible, and in spiritual influences
Any system of philosophy which refers the phenomena of nature as a blind force or forces acting necessarily or according to fixed laws, excluding origination or direction by a will.
A doctrine which denies a strong separation between scientific and philosophic methodologies and/or topics

A movement in theatre, film, and literature that seeks to replicate a believable everyday reality, as opposed to such movements as Romanticism or Surrealism, in which subjects may receive highly symbolic, idealistic, or even supernatural treatment.
naturism , social nudity .
(philosophy) the doctrine that the world can be understood in scientific terms without recourse to spiritual or supernatural explanations
an artistic movement in 19th century France; artists and writers strove for detailed realistic and factual description

nature.explanation: The material world and its phenomena.
The forces and processes that produce and control these phenomena.
The world of living things and the outdoors.
A primitive state of existence, untouched and uninfluenced by civilization or social constraints.
The basic character or qualities of humanity.
The fundamental character or disposition of a person; temperament: synonym : disposition .
The set of inherent characteristics or properties that distinguish something.
A kind or sort.
The processes and functions of the body, as in healing.
Heredity.
Birth; origin; parentage; original stock.

The forces or processes of the material world, conceived of as an agency intermediate between the Creator and the world, producing all organisms and preserving the regular order of things: as, in the old dictum, “ nature abhors a vacuum.” In this sense nature is often persouified.
The metaphysical principle of life; the power of growth; that which causes organisms to develop each in its predeterminate way.
Cel. Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune. … Those that she makes fair she scarce mates honest, and those that she makes honest she makes very ill-favouredly.
. Cause; occasion; that which produces anything.

The material and spiritual universe, as distinguished from the Creator; the system of things of whieh man forms a part; creation, especially that part of it which more immediately surrounds man and affects his senses, as mountains, seas, rivers, woods, etc.: as, the beauties of nature ; in a restricted sense, whatever is produced without artificial aid, and exists unchanged by man, and is thus opposed to art.
Hence That which is conformed to nature or to truth and reality, as distinguished from that which is artificial, forced, conventional, or remote from actual experience; naturalness.

Inherent constitution, property, or quality: essential character, quality, or kind; the qualities or attributes whieh constitute a being or thing what it is, and distinguish it from all others; also, kind; sort; species; category: as, the nature of the soul; the divine nature ; it is the nature of fire to burn; the compensation was in the nature of a fee.

An original, wild, undomesticated condition, as of an animal or a plant; also, the primitive condition of man antecedent to institutions, especially to political institutions: as, to live in a state of nature.

The primitive aboriginal instincts, qualities, and tendencies common to mankind of all races and in all ages, as unchanged or uninfluenced by civilization; especially, the instinctive or spontaneous sense of justice, benevolence, affection, self-preservation, love of show, etc., common to mankind; naturalness of thought, feeling, or action; humanity.
The physical or moral constitution of man; physical or moral being; the personality.

Inborn or innate character, disposition, or inclination; inherent bent or disposition; individual constitution or temperament; inbred or natural endowments, as opposed to acquired; hence, by metonymy, a person so endowed: as, we instinctively look up to a superior nature.
The vital powers of man; vitality; vital force; life; also, natural course of life; lifetime.
In theology , the natural unregenerate state of the soul; moral character in its original condition, unaffected by grace.
Conscience.
Spontaneity. abandon; felicity; truth; naturalness.
Kindly disposition: a natural disposition such that one does not readily take or give offense; an easy, indulgent spirit.
In theology , in a state of sin; unregencrated.
The regular course of human life.

nature grass; nature hay.

The personified sum and order of causes and effects; the powers which produce existing phenomena, whether in the total or in detail; the agencies which carry on the processes of creation or of being; -- often conceived of as a single and separate entity, embodying the total of all finite agencies and forces as disconnected from a creating or ordering intelligence.
The established or regular course of things; usual order of events; connection of cause and effect.

Necessary, Essential, Requisite, Needful. The following remarks refer to the application of the words to ordinary practical affairs, not to philosophy. Necessary is so general a word that it covers all the others, and has the additional sense, which they do not have, of inevitable. Essential is an absolute word, noting that which is a part of the chief end of the action, or of every mode of bringing that end about. Requisite is less strong than essential , and needful is less strong still; yet each is strong and emphatic, applying to that which is imperatively needed. Needful generally applies to concrete, and often to temporary, things: as, knowledge of the countries visited is requisite , and even essential , to enjoyment of travel, but money is needful in order to be able to travel at all. Needful is often applied to that which must be supplied to produce or effect a perfect state or action.
Anything that is necessary or indispensable; that which cannot be disregarded or omitted: as, the necessaries of life.
Such as must be; impossible to be otherwise; not to be avoided; inevitable.

neck.explanation: The part of the body joining the head to the shoulders or trunk.
A narrow or constricted area of a bodily structure, as of a bone, that joins its parts; a cervix.
The part of a tooth between the crown and root.
The part of a garment around or near the neck.
A relatively narrow elongation, projection, or connecting part.
The narrow part along which the strings of an instrument extend to the pegs.
Solidified lava filling the vent of an extinct volcano.
The siphon of a bivalve mollusk, such as a clam.
A narrow margin.
To kiss and caress amorously.
To strangle or decapitate (a fowl).
( neck and neck ) So close that the lead between competitors is virtually indeterminable.
( up to (one's) neck ) Deeply involved or occupied fully.
That part of an animal's body which is between the head and the trunk and connects these parts.
Figuratively life, from the breaking or severing of the neck in legal executions: as, to risk one's neck ; to save one's neck.
In entomology :
The membrane connecting the hard parts of an insect's head with those of the thorax, and visible only when the head is forcibly drawn out.
The posterior part of the head when this is suddenly narrowed behind the eyes.
A slender anterior prolongation of the prothorax found in certain Diptera and Hymenoptera.
In anatomy , a constricted part, or constriction of a part, like or likened to a neck: as, the neck of the thigh-bone; the neck of the bladder; the neck of the uterus. See cut under femur .
The flesh of the neck and adjoining parts: as, a neck of mutton.
That part of a thing which corresponds to or resembles the neck of an animal.
That part of a garment which covers the neck: as, the high neck of a gown.
The slender upper part of any vessel which has a larger rounded body: as, the neck of a bottle, retort, etc.

In stringed musical instruments of the viol and lute families, the long slender part extending upward from the body, culminating in the head where the tension is regulated, and bearing in front the finger-board over which the strings (or such of them as are to be stopped) are stretched.
The part of an axle that passes through the hub of the wheel; also, a diminished part of any shaft resting in a hearing.
The round shank connecting the blade and the socket of a bayonet.
The constricted part joining the knob to the breech of a gun.
The contracted part of a furnace over the bridge, between the stack and the heating- or melting-chamber.
In printing , the slope between the face and the shoulder of a type. Sometimes called beard .
In botany :
In mosses, the collum or tapering base of the capsule.
In histology, the rim or wall of the archegonium which projects above the prothallium. It rests upon the venter, and is ordinarily composed of four longitudinal rows of cells.

The filled-up pipe or channel through which volcanic material has found its way upward. In modern volcanic areas the vent through which the lava, cinders, or ashes are ejected and reach the surface is generally concealed from view by the accumulated material which has been thrown out. In eruptive regions belonging to the older geological systems denudation has occasionally removed the overlying debris, so that the connection of the volcanic orifice with the more deep-seated regions can be seen and examined. This is particularly the case in the Carboniferous and Permian volcanic areas of Scotland.
In the clamp process of brickmaking, one of a series of walls of unburned bricks which together constitute a clamp.
A small bundle of the best ears of a wheatharvest, used in the ceremony of “crying the neck.”
As a geographical designation, a corner or triangular district: as, Penn's Neck.
In surgery , a weak point in the shaft of the bone, a little below the tuberosities: so called from the frequency of fracture at this point.
To kiss and caress amorously.
To reduce the diameter of (an object) near its end, by making a groove around it; -- used with down.
The part of an animal which connects the head and the trunk, and which, in man and many other animals, is more slender than the trunk.
Any part of an inanimate object corresponding to or resembling the neck of an animal.
The long slender part of a vessel, as a retort, or of a fruit, as a gourd.
A long narrow tract of land projecting from the main body, or a narrow tract connecting two larger tracts.
That part of a violin, guitar, or similar instrument, which extends from the head to the body, and on which is the finger board or fret board.

neckatee.explanation: A neckerchief; a small shawl-shaped wrap.

neckband.explanation: The band around the collar of a garment.
The part of a shirt which encircles the neck; the band to which the collar is sewed, or to which a separate collar is buttoned.
A band which goes around the neck; often, the part at the top of a garment.
A band worn around the neck
a band around the collar of a garment
necklace that fits tightly around a woman's neck
a band that fits around the neck and is usually folded over

necked.explanation: Having a neck or neckline of a specified kind. Often used in combination.
Having (such) a neck; -- chiefly used in composition.
Having some specific type of neck
Simple past tense and past participle of neck .
having a neck or having a neck especially as specified (often used in combination)

neckerchief.explanation: A kerchief worn around the neck.
A kerchief for the neck; -- called also neck handkerchief .
A scarf that is worn looped or tied around the neck .
a kerchief worn around the neck

necking.explanation: A molding between the upper part of a column and the projecting part of the capital.
The act of kissing and caressing.

In arch. , the hypophyge or moldings often intervening between the projecting part of the capital of a column and the vertical part or shaft, as the annulets of the Doric capital: often used as a synonym of neck , though strictly a column may have a neck , but no necking. See cuts under capital and column.
A behavior among male giraffes where they hold combat for social dominance using their necks as weapons.
affectionate play (or foreplay without contact with the genital organs)
the molding at the top of a column

neckinger.explanation: A neck-handkerchief, specifically that worn by women in the eighteenth century.

necklace.explanation: An ornament worn around the neck.
Something felt to resemble this neck ornament, as in shape.
Any flexible ornament worn round the neck, us one of shells, coins, beads, or flowers.
A band or tie for the neck, of lace, silk, or the like, worn by women.
Nautical , a chain about a lower mast, to which the futtock-shrouds were formerly secured; a strap girding a lower mast and carrying leading-blocks.
In ceramics , a molding or continuous ornament applied to the shoulder or neck of a vase or bottle, especially when twisted, divided into beads, or the like.
A string of beads, etc., or any continuous band or chain, worn around the neck as an ornament.
A rope or chain fitted around the masthead to hold hanging blocks for jibs and stays.
An article of jewelry that is worn around the neck , most often made of a string of precious metal , pearls , gems , beads or shells , and sometimes having a pendant attached.
Anything resembling a necklace in shape.
A method of informal execution in which a rubber tyre is filled with petrol , placed around the victim 's chest and arms, and set on fire .
To informally execute by setting on fire a petrol-filled rubber tyre which has been put around the bound victim 's neck.
jewelry consisting of a cord or chain (often bearing gems) worn about the neck as an ornament (especially by women)

necklaced.explanation: Wearing a necklace; marked as with a necklace.
Simple past tense and past participle of necklace .

neckless.explanation: lacking or apparently lacking a neck; -- of a garment.
lacking or apparently lacking a neck

necklet.explanation: A type of ornament worn tightly about the neck .
decoration worn about the neck (fur piece or tight necklace) as an ornament

necklike.explanation: Resembling a neck or some aspect of one.

neckline.explanation: The line formed by the edge of a garment at or near the neck.
The line followed by an article of clothing below the neck .
the line formed by the edge of a garment around the neck

neckmold.explanation: A small convex molding surrounding a column at the junction of the shaft and capital.

neckmould.explanation: A small convex moulding surrounding a column at the junction of the shaft and capital .

neckpiece.explanation: An article of clothing, such as a scarf or strap, worn around the neck.
A piece of clothing to be worn around the neck .
an article of apparel worn about the neck

necks.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of neck .

necktie.explanation: A narrow fabric band of varying length worn around the neck and tied in a knot or bow close to the throat.
Properly, a narrow band, generally of silk or satin, worn around the neck, and tied in a knot in front; by extension, any band, scarf, or tie worn around the neck or fastened in front of the collar.
A scarf, band, or kerchief of silk, etc., passing around the neck or collar and tied in front; a bow of silk, etc., fastened in front of the neck.
A strip of cloth worn around the neck and tied in the front. See also bowtie .
neckwear consisting of a long narrow piece of material worn (mostly by men) under a collar and tied in knot at the front

neckwear.explanation: Articles, such as neckties, worn around the neck.
A collective term for cravats, collars, etc.
articles of clothing or jewelry which hang from the neck, such as ties or necklaces
articles of clothing worn about the neck

neckweed.explanation: A small, widely diffused plant, Veronica peregrina , once deemed efficacious in scrofula.
Hemp, as used for making ropes for hangmen's use.
An American annual weed ( veronica peregrina ), with small white flowers and a roundish pod.
The hemp; -- so called as furnishing ropes for hanging criminals.
An American annual weed (Veronica peregrina), with small white flowers and a roundish pod .
The hemp plant, which furnishes ropes for hanging criminals .

neckyoke.explanation: A yoke which touches or surrounds the carrier's neck, rather then just resting on the shoulders.

necro.explanation: To make a new post to a forum discussion that has been dormant for a long time, making the thread visible in the list of active topics; to bump .
To practice necromancy ; to bring back from the dead.

necrobacillosis.explanation: Any disease of animals produced by Bacillus necrophorus and characterized by caseone-crotic lesions.

necrobiosis.explanation: The natural death of cells or tissues through aging, as distinguished from necrosis or pathological death.
In pathology , degenerative progress toward and ending in the death of a portion of tissue.
In biology , the doctrine or opinion that living beings may arise from decomposing organic matter: contrasted with the opinion that they may be spontaneously generated from inorganic matter.

The death of a part of an organism by molecular disintegration and without loss of continuity, as in the processes of degeneration and atrophy; a normal dying out of cells in a tissue, in contrast to necrosis .
The normal death of cells or tissues because of age - related changes .
(physiology) the normal degeneration and death of living cells (as in various epithelial cells)

necrolatry.explanation: Worship of the dead; worship of the spirits of the dead, or of ancestors; excessive veneration or sentimental reverence toward the dead.
The worship of the dead; manes worship.
The practice of worshipping or revering the dead.

necrologic.explanation: Of or pertaining to necrology; of the nature of necrology; relating to, or giving, an account of the dead, or of deaths.

necrological.explanation: Of or pertaining to a necrology .

necrologist.explanation: One who gives an aecount of deaths; one who writes or prepares obituary notices.
One who gives an account of deaths.
A person who compiles a necrology .

necrology.explanation: A list of people who have died, especially in the recent past or during a specific period.
A register of persons, as members of a society, etc., who die within a certain time; an obituary, or a collection of obituary notices.
Formerly, in religious houses, a book which contained the names of persons for whose souls prayer was to be offered, as founders of the establishment, benefactors, and members.
An account of deaths, or of the dead; a register of deaths; a collection of obituary notices.
A church register containing the names of those connected with the church who have died.
A listing of people who have died during a specific period of time.
A notice of death ; an obituary .
The study of death or the dead.
a notice of someone's death; usually includes a short biography
a list of people who died recently

necromancer.explanation: One who practises necromancy; a conjurer; a sorcerer; a wizard.
One who practices necromancy; a sorcerer; a wizard.
one who practices magic or sorcery
one who practices divination by conjuring up the dead

necromancing.explanation: The art or practices of a necromancer; conjuring.

necromancy.explanation: The practice of supposedly communicating with the spirits of the dead in order to predict the future.
Divination by calling up the spirits of the dead and conversing with them; the pretended summoning of apparitions of the dead in order that they may answer questions.
The art of magic in general; enchantment; conjuration; the black art.
The art of revealing future events by means of a pretended communication with the dead; the black art; hence, magic in general; conjuration; enchantment. See black art .
Divination involving the dead or death .
Loosely, any sorcery or witchcraft, especially involving death or the dead, particularly sorcery involving raising or reanimating the dead.
the belief in magical spells that harness occult forces or evil spirits to produce unnatural effects in the world
conjuring up the dead, especially for prophesying

necromania.explanation: A morbid attraction toward death or the dead.
An abnormal attraction to dead bodies.
an irresistible sexual attraction to dead bodies

necromantic.explanation: A magical or conjuring trick; a magical act; conjuring.
Of or pertaining to necromancy; performed by necromancy.
Of or referring to necromancy : the resurrection of or communication with the dead, especially through the use of black magic .
relating to or associated with necromancy
given to or produced by or used in the art of conjuring up the dead

necromantical.explanation: relating to or associated with necromancy

necronite.explanation: Fetid feldspar, a variety of orthoclase.
Fetid feldspar, a mineral which, when struck, exhales a fetid odor.
fetid feldspar , a mineral that gives off an unpleasant odour when struck.

necrophagan.explanation: A member of the Neerophaga , as a burying-, sexton-, or carrion-beetle.
Any of the tribe Necrophaga of beetles whose larvae feed on carrion .

necrophagia.explanation: The act or practice of feeding on dead bodies or carrion.
the consumption of dead flesh or carrion
the practice of feeding on ( eating ) corpses

necrophagous.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Necrophaga ; eating carrion. See necrophagan .
That eats dead or decaying animal flesh .

necrophagy.explanation: The eating of dead or decaying animal flesh

necrophile.explanation: One who is subject to necrophilia .

necrophilia.explanation: Obsessive fascination with death and corpses.
A paraphilia in which sexual gratification is derived from fantasies or acts involving a corpse.
A pathological attraction to dead bodies, especially sexual attraction or intercourse .
an irresistible sexual attraction to dead bodies

necrophiliac.explanation: a person who engages in necrophilia

necrophilism.explanation: An unnatural or morbid state characterized by a revolting attraction toward the dead. It manifests itself in various ways, those subject to it living beside dead bodies, exhuming corpses to see them, kiss them, or mutilate them, etc. Necrophilism sometimes develops into a sort of canuibalism.
an irresistible sexual attraction to dead bodies

necrophobia.explanation: An abnormal fear of death or corpses.
A morbid horror of dead bodies.
Ail exaggerated fear of death; thanatophobia.
An exaggerated fear of death or horror of dead bodies.
an abnormal fear of death or corpses

necrophorus.explanation: The typical genus of Necropho-ricdæ , having ten-jointed antennæ.

necropolis.explanation: A cemetery, especially a large and elaborate one belonging to an ancient city.
A cemetery; specifically, one of the cemeteries of ancient peoples.
A city of the dead; a name given by the ancients to their cemeteries, and sometimes applied to modern burial places; a graveyard.
A large cemetery , especially one of elaborate construction in an ancient city.
a tract of land used for burials

necropsied.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of necropsy .

necropsy.explanation: A post-mortem examination or inspection; an autopsy. See autopsy .
The pathological dissection of a corpse ; particularly to determine cause of death. Applicable to the examination of any life form.
The act of performing a necropsy.
an examination and dissection of a dead body to determine cause of death or the changes produced by disease

necroscopic.explanation: Or or relating to post-mortem examinations.
of, or relating to a post mortem examination.

necroscopy.explanation: The examination of a body after death; post-mortem examination; autopsy. Also necropsy .

necrose.explanation: To undergo or cause to undergo necrosis.
To affect with necrosis; to undergo necrosis.

necrosed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of necrose .

necroses.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of necrose .

necrotic.explanation: Affected with necrosis; ; characterized by, or producing, necrosis.
Of or pertaining to necrosis , particularly of tissue.
relating to or affected by necrosis

necrotised.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of necrotise .

necrotize.explanation: To undergo necrosis or cause to necrose.
To undergo, or to cause necrosis ; to become or to make necrotic

necrotized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of necrotize .

necrotomy.explanation: A surgical operation for the removal of necrosed bone.
The dissection of dead bodies; also, excision of necrosed bone.
The surgical removal of dead tissue, especially bone .

necrotype.explanation: A type formerly extant in any region, afterward extinct: thus, indigenous horses and rhinoceroses are necrotypes of North Ameriea.

nectandra.explanation: A genus of trees of the apetalous order Laurineæ and the tribe Perseaceæ , known by the anthers with four cells in a curving line.

nectar.explanation: A sweet liquid that many plants secrete from specialized structures, often inside flowers, where it serves to attract pollinators such as certain insects and birds. Bees use nectar to make honey.
A beverage containing fruit juice or purée.
In classical mythology , the drink or wine of the Olympian gods, poured out for them by Hebe and Ganymede, the cupbearers of Zeus.
Hence, any delicious and salubrious drink.
In botany , the honey of a flower; the superfluous saccharine matter remaining after the stamens and pistils have consumed all that they require.
The drink of the gods (as ambrosia was their food); hence, any delicious or inspiring beverage.
A sweetish secretion of blossoms from which bees make honey.
(classical mythology) the food and drink of the gods; mortals who ate it became immortal
a sweet liquid secretion that is attractive to pollinators

nectareal.explanation: Of or pertaining to a nectary.
Of or pertaining to nectar ; nectareous; sweet .

nectarean.explanation: Resembling nectar; very sweet and pleasant.
Of or pertaining to nectar ; nectareous; sweet .

nectared.explanation: Imbued with nectar; mingled with nectar; abounding with nectar.

nectareous.explanation: Of, pertaining to, containing, or resembling nectar; delicious; nectarean.

nectarial.explanation: Of or pertaining to the nectary of a plant.
Of or pertaining to the nectary of a plant .

nectariferous.explanation: Secreting nectar; -- said of blossoms or their parts.

nectarine.explanation: A variety of peach tree having small aromatic fruit with smooth reddish skin.
The soft juicy fruit of this tree.
A variety of the common peach, from which its fruit differs only in having a rind devoid of down and a firmer pulp. Both fruits are sometimes found growing on the same tree. See peach .
the plumlike fruit of the West Indian tree Chrysobalanus Icaco ; -- also called cocoa plum . It is made into a sweet conserve which is largely exported from Cuba.
A cultivar of the peach distinguished by the absence of peachfuzz on the skin.
variety or mutation of the peach bearing fruit with smooth skin and (usually) yellow flesh
a variety or mutation of the peach that has a smooth skin

nectarinia.explanation: The representative genus of the family Nectariniidæ , in which the middle tail-feathers of the male are long-exserted. The species are African. N. famosa is an example. Cinnyris is a synonym.

nectarize.explanation: To mingle or infuse with nectar; to sweeten.
To mingle or infuse with nectar ; to sweeten .

nectarized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of nectarize .

nectarous.explanation: consisting of, having the qualities of, or resembling nectar
extremely pleasing to the taste; sweet and fragrant

nectary.explanation: A nectar-secreting structure located either within a flower or on a leaf or other part of a plant.
In botany , a part of a flower that contains or secretes a saccharine fluid.
In entomology , one of two little tubular organs on the abdomen of an aphis or plant-louse, from which a sweet fluid like honey is exuded. Also called honey-tube, siphuncle , or cornicle.

That part of a blossom which secretes nectar, usually the base of the corolla or petals; also, the spur of such flowers as the larkspur and columbine, whether nectariferous or not. See the Illustration of nasturtium .
a gland (often a protuberance or depression) that secretes nectar

nectocalyx.explanation: A swimming-bell; the bell-shaped or discoidal natatory organ with which many hydrozoans are provided, and by means of which the hydrosome is propelled through the water.
The swimming bell or umbrella of a jellyfish of medusa.
One of the zooids of certain Siphonophora, having somewhat the form, and the essential structure, of the bell of a jellyfish, and acting as a swimming organ.
The swimming bell or umbrella of a jellyfish or medusa .
One of the zooids of certain Siphonophora , having somewhat the form, and the essential structure, of the bell of a jellyfish, and acting as a swimming organ.

necton.explanation: A name introduced by Haeckel in 1890 for the entire assemblage of aquatic animals that lead an actively swimming life. A torpedo-like form, bilateral symmetry, and highly developed swimming-musculature characterize this group, of which the fishes, whales, and squids are examples.

nectophore.explanation: The swimming bell of a siphonophore

nectria.explanation: A large genus of pyrenomycetous fungi of the family Hypocreaceæ having the perithecia membranous, single, or variously aggregated on a stroma, and usually bright-colored.
pl. nectrias. Any fungus of the genus Nectria. See apple-tree and plum canker, cacao and coral-spot disease , and Tubercularia.

necturus.explanation: A genus of amphibians: same as Menobranchus .

ned.explanation: A person, usually a youth, of low social standing and education, a violent disposition and with a particular style of dress (typically sportswear or Burberry), speech and behaviour.

nedder.explanation: A form of nadder , usually adder. See nadder, adder .

neddy.explanation: A pet name for a donkey.

neddy.category: Australia, slang, in the plural, with "the"

neddy.explanation: An idiot ; a stupid or contemptible person.

nee.explanation: née Necker (that is, Madame de Staël, born Necker, or whose family name was Necker).
Used when giving the maiden name of a woman.
Used when giving a former name. Originally known as.
no , used to express no as a quantity, i.e. not any, like German kein /Dutch geen /French rien . Compare with na .
(meaning literally `born') used to indicate the maiden or family name of a married woman

need.explanation: A condition or situation in which something must be supplied in order for a certain condition to be maintained or a desired state to be achieved.
Something required or wanted; a requisite.
Necessity; obligation.
A condition of poverty or misfortune.
To be under the necessity of or the obligation to.
To have need of; require.

To be subject (to an action) by obligation.
To want to be subject to.
To be in need or want.
To be necessary.
Ward , etc. See lack .
The lack of something that is necessary or important; urgent want; necessity.
Specifically, want of the means of subsistence; destitution; poverty; indigence; distress; privation.
Time of want; exigency; emergency: as, “a friend in need is a friend indeed.”
That which is needful; something necessary to be done.
A perilous extremity.
Synonyms Necessity, Need (see necessity and exigency ) emergency, strait, extremity, distress.
Want, Indigence , etc. See poverty .
To be wanted; to be necessary.
Of necessity. See needs .
A state that requires supply or relief; pressing occasion for something; necessity; urgent want.
Want of the means of subsistence; poverty; indigence; destitution.
That which is needful; anything necessary to be done; (pl.) necessary things; business.
Situation of need; peril; danger.
To be in want of; to have cause or occasion for; to lack; to require, as supply or relief.
A requirement for something.
Something required.
To be necessary (to someone).
To have an absolute requirement for.
To want strongly; to feel that one must have something.
To be obliged or required (to do something).
a condition requiring relief
anything that is necessary but lacking
a state of extreme poverty or destitution
have need of
require as useful, just, or proper
have or feel a need for
the psychological feature that arouses an organism to action toward a desired goal; the reason for the action; that which gives purpose and direction to behavior

needed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of need .

needer.explanation: A person who requires or needs something.
a person who wants or needs something

needfire.explanation: A fire produced by the friction of one piece of wood upon another, or of a rope upon a stake of wood.
The phosphoric light of rotten wood.

needful.explanation: Needy people considered as a group.
Full of need; in need or want; needy; distressing.
Necessary for supply or relief; requisite.

needfulness.explanation: The state of being needful; necessity.
The property of being needful or necessary .

needier.explanation: comparative form of needy : more needy

neediest.explanation: superlative form of needy : most needy .

needily.explanation: In a needy condition or manner; necessarily.

neediness.explanation: The state of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
The state or quality of being needy; want; poverty; indigence.
the quality of needing attention and affection and reassurance to a marked degree

needle.explanation: A slender, pointed implement used for sewing or surgical suturing, made usually of polished steel and having an eye at one end through which a length of thread is passed and held.
Any of various similar implements, such as a fine sharp-pointed instrument used in acupuncture or a pointed shaft used in knitting, crocheting, or lace making.
A sharp-pointed instrument used in engraving.
A slender piece of jewel or steel used to transmit vibrations from the grooves of a phonograph record.
A slender pointer or indicator on a dial, scale, or similar part of a mechanical device.
A magnetic needle.
A hypodermic needle.
A hypodermic injection; a shot.
A narrow stiff leaf, as of a pine or fir.
A fine, sharp projection, as a spine of a sea urchin or a crystal.
A tall narrow rock formation.
An obelisk.
A goading, provoking, or teasing remark or act.
To prick, pierce, or stitch with a needle.
To goad, provoke, or tease.
To sew or do similar work with a needle.
plural In mining : Beams laid across a mine shaft to support a cage.
Buntons.
A small pointed instrument, straight or curved, for carrying a thread through a woven fabric, paper, leather, felt, or other material.
In a wider sense, any slender pointed instrument shaped like a needle or used in a similar way: as, a knitting-, crochet-, or engraving- needle; a surgeons' needle.
Anything resembling a needle in shape.

Specifically— A small piece of steel pointed at both ends, and balanced centrally on a pivot, such as is used in the magnetic compass, in which it points to the magnetic poles, and in the needle-telegraph, in which its deflections, produced by electric currents, are used to give indications. See compass, magnet, dipping-needle, galvanometer , and needle-telegraph.

A thin rod, usually made of copper, which is inserted in a drill-hole while this is being charged with powder. When the rod is withdrawn, it leaves a space in which can be inserted the tube of rush or grass, or the fuse, by which the charge is ignited. Also called a blasting-needle , or a nail
In w eaving , a horizontal piece of wire with an eye to receive the lifting-wire in a Jacquard loom.
A sharp pinnacle of rock; a detached pointed rock
In chem. and mineralogy , a crystal shaped like a needle; an aciform crystal.
In zool , a slender, sharp spicule; an aciculum.
In bot , a needle-shaped leaf, as of a conifer: as, a pine - needle.

In a central-fire hammerlesa gun of the variety called needle-gun , a pointed, slender, longitudinally sliding bolt or wire which, being driven forcibly forward by the spring-mechanism of the lock when the gun is tired, strikes with its front end against a fulminate or fulminating compound attached to the interior of the cartridge. The famous Prussian needle-gun is believed to be the first gun constructed to be fired on this principle. See cut under needle-gun .

In architecture , a piece of timber laid horizontally and supported on props or shores under a wall or building, etc., which it serves to sustain temporarily while the foundation or the part beneath is being altered, repaired, or underpinned.
A beam carrying a pulley at the end projecting from a building. The fall is worked by a crab inside the building.
To form needles; to crystallize in the form of needles.
To form in the shape of a needle.
To tease (a person), especially repeatedly.
To prod or goad (someone) into action by teasing or daring.
A small instrument of steel, sharply pointed at one end, with an eye to receive a thread, -- used in sewing.
See Magnetic needle, under Magnetic .

A slender rod or wire used in knitting; a knitting needle; also, a hooked instrument which carries the thread or twine, and by means of which knots or loops are formed in the process of netting, knitting, or crocheting.
One of the needle-shaped secondary leaves of pine trees. See Pinus .

Nefarious, Execrable, Flagitious, Enormous, Villainous, Abominable, Horrible , atrocious, infamous, iniquitous, impious, dreadful, detestable. The first seven words characterize extreme wickedness. As with the words under atrocious , when loosely used they approach each other in meaning; hence only their primary meanings will be indicated here: nefarious , unspeakably wicked, impious; execrable , worthy of execration or cursing, utterly hateful; flagitious , proceeding from burning desire (as lust), grossly or brutally wicked or vile, enormous , not common in this sense except with a strong noun, as enormous wickedness, but sometimes meaning wicked beyond common measure; villainous , worthy of a villain, greatly criminal or capable of great crimes; abominable , loathsome in wickedness, the object of a religious detestation; horrible , exciting horror, mental agitation, or shrinking; shocking: it is less common as applied to moral conduct, See abandoned, atrocious, criminal , and irreligious.

Neglect, Disregard, Slight. Slight always expresses intention: it applies to persons or things. Neglect and disregard apply more often to things, and may or may not express intention; disregard is more often intentional than neglect. Only neglect may be followed by an infinitive: as, to neglect to write a letter; among things it generally applies to action that is needed, while disregard commonly applies to failure to heed or notice: as, to disregard counsel, a hint, a request, the lessons of experience, the signs of coming rain; to neglect a duty. See negligent and negligence.

1 and Negligence, Neglect, Remissness, Inattention, Inadvertence, Oversight, Indifference. As contrasted with neglect, negligence generally expresses the habit or trait, and neglect the act. Inadvertence and oversight expressly mean that there was no intention of neglect; indifference lies back of action in the failure to care, such failure being generally blameworthy. Remissness is careless neglect of duty. Inattention is a failure. generally culpable, to bring the mind to the subject. See neglect, n. t , and negligent.

Negligent, Neglectful, Remiss, Heedless, Thoughtless. inattentive, regardless, indifferent, slack. Of the first five words, remiss is the weakest; it especially applies to failure to attend to what is considered duty. Negligent is generally applied to inattention to things, neglectful to inattention to persons. Neglectful , by derivation, is stronger than negligent , but the difference is really small. Heedless, thoughtless , etc., indicate lack of heed, care, attention, thought, etc., where they are needed or due. All these words may apply to a particular occasion of failure, or indicate a habit or a trait of character; as, he is very heedless. See neglect , v., and negligence.
