One who lives near another; one who forms part of a circumscribed community; a person in relation to those who dwell near him, in the houses adjacent, or, by extension, in the same village or town.
One who stands or sits near another; one in close proximity.
A person in relation to his fellow-men, regarded as having social and moral duties toward them.
One who lives on friendly terms with another: often used as a familiar term of address: as, neighbor Jones.
An intimate; a confidant.
neighbor village; neighbor farmers.
A person who lives near another; one whose abode is not far off.
One who is near in sympathy or confidence.
One entitled to, or exhibiting, neighborly kindness; hence, one of the human race; a fellow being.
Near to another; adjoining; adjacent; next; neighboring.
To dwell in the vicinity; to be a neighbor, or in the neighborhood; to be near.
To adjoin; to border on; to be near to.
To associate intimately with.
Alternative spelling of neighbour .
Alternative spelling of neighbour .
live or be located as a neighbor
a nearby object of the same kind
be located near or adjacent to
a person who lives (or is located) near another

neighbored.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of neighbor .

neighborer.explanation: One who neighbors, or stands in close proximity to another; a neighbor.

neighborhood.explanation: A district or area with distinctive characteristics.
The people who live near one another or in a particular district or area.
The surrounding area; vicinity.
Approximate amount or range.
Friendliness appropriate to a neighbor.
The set of points surrounding a specified point, each of which is within a certain, usually small distance from the specified point.

In mathematics , the part of a line, surface, space, or other locus in quo so near to a correlative point that from its utmost parts to that point it has everywhere a certain given character with respect to which it is the neighborhood of that point. Thus, to say that the air is condensed in the neighborhood of a certain point, is to say that after one has approached it sufficiently near, the nearer one approaches the more condensed is the air up to the point itself.
The condition or quality of being neighbors; the state of dwelling or being situated nigh or near; proximity; nearness: as, neighborhood often promotes friendship.
Conduct as a neighbor.
The kindliness and mutual readiness to be friendly which arise out of the condition of being neighbors; the reciprocity and mutual helpfulness becoming to neighbors; neighborly feelings and acts.
The place or locality lying next or nigh to some specified place; adjoining district; vicinity: as he lived in my neighborhood : frequently used figuratively.
Those living in the vicinity or adjoining locality; neighbors collectively; as, thė fire alarmed the whole neighborhood.
A district or locality, especially when considered with reference to its inhabitants or their interests: as, a fashionable neighborhood ; a malarious neighborhood.

Synonyms and Neighborhood, Vicinity, Proximity. The first two differ from proximity in being used concretely: as, the explosion was heard throughout the neighborhood or vicinity (but not proximity ). Neighborhood is closer and livelier than vicinity; proximity is the closest nearness. Neighborhood regards not only place, but persons; vicinity only the place; hence we say he lived in the vicinity of New York or the Hudson, but he lived in the neighborhood of Irving; his house was in close proximity to the one that was on fire. See adjacent .
The quality or condition of being a neighbor; the state of being or dwelling near; proximity.
A place near; vicinity; adjoining district; a region the inhabitants of which may be counted as neighbors.
The inhabitants who live in the vicinity of each other.
The disposition becoming a neighbor; neighborly kindness or good will.
The quality of being a neighbor , living nearby , next to each-other
A nearby area .
The inhabitants of a residential area.
A division of a municipality or region, formally or informally divided
An approximate amount.
The quality of physical proximity .
The disposition becoming a neighbor; neighborly kindness or good will.
The neighborhood of a point x is... (depending on the author):
a surrounding or nearby region
the approximate amount of something (usually used prepositionally as in `in the region of')
an area within a city or town that has some distinctive features (especially one forming a community)
people living near one another

neighboring.explanation: Situated or living nearby or adjacent to.
having a common boundary or edge; abutting; touching

neighborliness.explanation: The state or quality of being neighborly in feelings or acts.
The quality or state of being neighborly.
a disposition to be friendly and helpful to neighbors

neighborly.explanation: Having or exhibiting the qualities of a friendly neighbor.
Appropriate to the relation of neighbors; having frequent or familiar intercourse; kind; civil; social; friendly.
Having or exhibiting the qualities of a friendly neighbor .
exhibiting the qualities expected in a friendly neighbor

neighbors.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of neighbor .

neighborship.explanation: The state or condition of being neighbors ; a community , connection , or relationship between or among people and/or things which is based simply on living close geographically.
A community , connection , or relationship between or among people and/or things which is based simply on being of a similar class.

neighbour.explanation: A person living on adjacent or nearby land; a person situated adjacently or nearby; anything (of the same type of thing as the subject) in an adjacent or nearby position.
To be adjacent to (more often used as neighbouring )
be located near or adjacent to
live or be located as a neighbor
a nearby object of the same kind
a person who lives (or is located) near another

neighboured.explanation: The state or condition of being a neighbour ; neighbourhood ; neighbourship .
Simple past tense and past participle of neighbour .

neighbourhood.explanation: Close proximity , particularly in reference to home
a division of a municipality or region, formally or informally divided
The quality or condition of being a neighbour; the state of being or dwelling near; proximity .
The infinitesimal open set of all points that may be reached directly from a given point; The set of all the vertices adjacent to a given vertex
The disposition becoming a neighbour; neighbourly kindness or good will.

neighbouring.explanation: Situated or living nearby or adjacent to.

neighbourliness.explanation: a disposition to be friendly and helpful to neighbors

neighbourly.explanation: Showing the qualities of a friendly and helpful neighbour .
exhibiting the qualities expected in a friendly neighbor

neighbours.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of neighbour .

neighbourship.explanation: The state or condition of being neighbours; a connection or relationship between people or things which is based simply on living close geographically.
A relationship between people and / or things which is based simply on being of a similar class .

neighed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of neigh .

neighing.explanation: The cry of a horse; a whinnying.
The sound made by a horse; an act or instance of the verb neigh.

neighs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of neigh .

neillia.explanation: A genus of branching shrubs, of the order Rosaceæ and the tribe Spiræeæ , known by the copious albumen and by the carpels varying from one to five.

There are 4 or 5 species, of North America, Manchuria, and mountains of India and Java. They bear alternate lobed leaves and clustered white flowers followed by purplish pods. N. ( Spiræa ) opulifolia , called ninebark from the numerous layers of its loose bark, is common in the interior of the United States, and is sometimes planted.

neither.explanation: either ), preceding one of a series of two or more alternative clauses, and correlative with nor (or, formerly, neither or ne ) before the following clause or clauses.
Not either; not the one or the other.
Not either; generally used to introduce the first of two or more coördinate clauses of which those that follow begin with nor .
not one of two; not either
not either; not one or the other

nek.explanation: In South Africa, a neck or saddle between two hills.

nekton.explanation: The collection of marine and freshwater organisms that can swim freely and are generally independent of currents, ranging in size from microscopic organisms to whales.
Swimming organisms considered collectively and in contrast with those that float and those that live upon or in the bottom. See plankton , benthos .
The aggregate of actively swimming animals in a body of water ranging from microscopic organisms to whales.
A generic term for organisms in the ocean that are capable of swimming independently of currents.
the aggregate of actively swimming animals in a body of water ranging from microscopic organisms to whales

nelly.explanation: Used as a disparaging term for an effeminate gay man.
A common name for the giant petrels , Macronectes giganteus and Macronectes halli

nelson.explanation: Any of several wrestling holds in which the user places an arm under the opponent's upper arm or armpit and presses the wrist or the palm of the hand against the back of the opponent's neck.
A score of 111, sometimes considered to be unlucky (supposedly from the belief that Lord Nelson had one eye, one arm and one leg (disputed)).
A wrestling hold in which a wrestler 's arm is locked behind his back .

nelumbium.explanation: In decorative art , the lotus-flower represented conventionally, especially when supporting the figure of a divine personage. See lotus .

nelumbo.explanation: A genus of water-lilies, forming the tribe Nelumboneæ in the order Nymphæaceæ , known by the broadly obconical receptacle.
A genus of great water lilies. The North American species is Nelumbo lutea , the Asiatic is the sacred lotus, Nelumbo speciosa .
Any of the genus Nelumbo of aquatic plants with large, showy flowers resembling water lilies .
sometimes placed in the family Nymphaeaceae: lotuses

nelumbonaceae.explanation: in some classifications considered an independent family of water lilies; comprises the single genus Nelumbo

nema.explanation: The flexuous filiform process by which the sicula and rhabdosome of graptolites are suspended from the primary disk. It attains great length in the young of certain forms, as in Dictyograptus, Dictyonema flabelliforme , and in certain Axonolipa , as species of Tetragraptus.

nemaline.explanation: Having the form of threads; fibrous.
Having the form of threads ; fibrous .

nemalion.explanation: A small genus of marine algæ. typical of the suborder Nemalieæ , with repeatedly dichotomous gelatinous fronds.

nemalite.explanation: The fibrous variety of brucite, or native hydrate of magnesium.

nemathecium.explanation: A wart-like elevation developed on the surface of the thallus of some of the higher algæ ( Florideæ ), and ordinarily containing clusters of tetraspores mixed with barren hyphæ or paraphyses: but in some forms the antheridia and cystocarps are also produced in similar protuberances.
A peculiar kind of fructification on certain red algæ, consisting of an external mass of filaments at length separating into tetraspores.
A kind of fructification on certain red algae , consisting of an external mass of filaments that separate into tetraspores .

nematic.explanation: Of or relating to the mesomorphic phase of a liquid crystal in which the molecules are oriented in loose parallel lines.
Describing the structure of some liquid crystals whose molecules align in loose parallel lines.

nematicide.explanation: Any pesticide designed to kill nematodes ( roundworms )

nematocera.explanation: Diptera , containing the numerous insects known as gnats, midges, mosquitos, crane-flies, gall-flies, etc.: so called from the long thready antennæ.
A suborder of dipterous insects, having long antennæ, as the mosquito, gnat, and crane fly; -- called also Nemocera .
mosquitoes; fungus gnats; crane flies; gnats; sand flies

nematocidal.explanation: Having the property of killing nematodes; lethal to nematodes.
Acting as a nematocide ; fatal to nematodes .

nematocide.explanation: A substance or agent used to kill nematodes.
A substance that kills nematoid worms.
A substance that kills nematodes, especially one used in medicine or to kill plant pathogens.
any compound used to kill nematode parasites in plants

nematocyst.explanation: A capsule within specialized cells in the tentacles of cnidarians, such as jellyfish and corals, containing a barbed, threadlike tube that delivers a toxic sting to predators and prey.

A thread-cell or lasso-cell; a cnidocell or cnida; one of the organs of offense and defense peculiar to cœlenterates, as jellyfishes, by means of which they sting. See cuts under cnida, Actinozoa , and Willsia.
A lasso cell, or thread cell. See lasso cell , under lasso .
A capsule , in certain cnidarians , containing a barbed , threadlike tube that delivers a paralyzing sting

nematoda.explanation: A phylum of worms, having a long, round, and generally smooth body; the roundworms. They are mostly parasites, in plants and animals, but some are free-living in soil or water. Also called Nematoidea .

nematode.explanation: Any of numerous worms of the phylum Nematoda, having unsegmented cylindrical bodies often narrowing at each end, and including free-living species that are abundant in soil and water, and species that are parasites of plants and animals, such as eelworms, pinworms, and hookworms.
Any worm of the phylum Nematoda; a roundworm; -- they are unsegmented worms having a cylindrical elongated body. They may live freely in soil or water, or as parasites in plants or animals.
A small invertebrate animal of the phylum Nematoda.
unsegmented worms with elongated rounded body pointed at both ends; mostly free-living but some are parasitic

nematogen.explanation: The vermiform embryo of a nematoid worm; one of the phases or stages of nematoid embryos: opposed to rhombogen. See cut under Dicyema .

nematogene.explanation: One of the dimorphic forms of the species of Dicyemata, which produced vermiform embryos; -- opposed to rhombogene .
One of the dimorphic forms of the species of Dicyemata, which produced vermiform embryos ; opposed to rhombogene .

nematogenic.explanation: Describing a solid that forms a nematic liquid crystal when heated

nematognath.explanation: A member of the Nematognathi ; any catfish.

nematognathi.explanation: An order of fishes having barbels on the jaws. It includes the catfishes, or siluroids. See siluroid .

nematoid.explanation: A threadworm, hairworm, roundworm, or pinworm. Also nematode, nematoidean.
Of or pertaining to the Nematoda.
Of, relating to, or resembling a nematode .

nematology.explanation: The branch of zoology that deals with nematodes.
The branch of biology that studies nematode roundworms

nemean.explanation: Of or pertaining to Nemea, in Argolis, where the ancient Greeks celebrated games, and Hercules killed a lion.

nemertean.explanation: Any of various unsegmented chiefly carnivorous worms of the phylum Nemertea (or Nemertini) that have a long, often brightly colored body with an extensible proboscis and typically live in the sea or in the mud of the intertidal zone.
A worm of the class Nemertea.
Of or pertaining to the Nemertina.
Any of several unsegmented, brightly-coloured worms , of the phylum Nemertea ; the ribbon worms
soft unsegmented marine worms that have a threadlike proboscis and the ability to stretch and contract

nemertine.explanation: Any of an order (Nemertina) of soft unsegmented marine worms having an eversible threadlike proboscis and the ability to stretch and contract.
soft unsegmented marine worms that have a threadlike proboscis and the ability to stretch and contract

nemertini.explanation: A class of elongated wormlike marine animals having a ciliated ectoderm, as in the Turbellaria , and an eversible proboscis lying in a sheath on the dorsal side of the enteron. They have a mouth and an anus, simple gonads, and a vascular system; and are, as a rule, diœcious. There is no external segmentation as in the more highly organized class of Chætopoda.

nemertoid.explanation: Nemertea , or having their characters; nemertean; nemertine.

nemesia.explanation: A genus of South African plants of the family Scrophulariaceæ. It contains about 30 species, annual or perennial herbs bearing white, yellow, or red short-tubular, solitary, or raeemed saccate or spurred flowers. A few of them are in cultivation as garden annuals, one of the most advertised being N. strumosa.

nemesis.explanation: A source of harm or ruin.
Retributive justice in its execution or outcome.
An opponent that cannot be beaten or overcome.
One that inflicts retribution or vengeance.
The goddess of retributive justice or vengeance.
In Greek myth , a goddess personifying allotment, or the divine distribution to every man of his precise share of fortune, good and bad.
[NL.] In zoology , a genus of crustaceans.
The 128th planetoid, discovered by Watson in 1872.
The goddess of retribution or vengeance; hence, retributive justice personified; divine vengeance.
A person or character who specifically brings about the downfall of another person or character
A punishment or defeat that is deserved and cannot be avoided.
The polar opposite of a character.
A righteous infliction of retribution manifested by an appropriate agent.
(Greek mythology) the goddess of divine retribution and vengeance

nemichthys.explanation: A genus of apodal fishes having a thread-like tail, typical of the family Nemichthyidæ. N. scolopaceus is a deep-sea form known as snipe-fish.

nemocera.explanation: Tipula and Culex of Linnæus, or the crane-flies, midges, gnats, etc. It is equivalent to the modern suborder Nematocera.

nemoceran.explanation: A dipterous insect of the suborder Nemocera.

nemocerous.explanation: Nemocera , or having their characters; having filamentous antennæ: nematocerous.

nemophila.explanation: A genus of ornamental plants of the gamopetalous order Hydrophyllaceæ and the tribe Hydrophylleæ , known by the included stamens and the calyx with appendages; the grove-love.
any plant of the genus Nemophila

nemophilist.explanation: One who is fond of woods and groves.
One who is fond of forest or forest scenery; a haunter of the woods.
One who is fond of forests or forest scenery ; a haunter of the woods .

nemophily.explanation: Love of the woods; fondness for a woodland life.
Fondness for forest scenery; love of the woods.

nemoral.explanation: Of or pertaining to a wood or grove.

nene.explanation: A rare wild goose (Branta sandvicensis) of the Hawaiian Islands, having a grayish-brown body with a black face.
A species of goose, Bernicla sandwichensis , peculiar to the Sandwich Islands.
The Hawaiian goose , Branta sandvicensis, now the state bird of Hawaii .

nenuphar.explanation: The great white water-lily of Europe, Castalia speciosa ( Nymphæa alba ); also, the yellow water-lily, Nymphæa ( Nuphar ) lutea.
The great white water lily of Europe; the Nymphæa alba .
A water lily , especially the common white water lily (Nymphaea alba) or the yellow water lily (Nuphar lutea).

neoarsphenamine.explanation: A derivative of arsphenamine once used to treat syphilis and yaws .

neobotanist.explanation: A botanist proper, as distinguished from a paleobotanist.

neobotany.explanation: Botany proper, as distinguished from paleobotany.

neocene.explanation: In geology , the later Tertiary, including the Miocene and Pliocene.
In geology , the later Tertiary, including the Miocene and Pliocene.
More recent than the Eocene, that is, including both the Miocene and Pliocene divisions of the Tertiary.

neoceratodus.explanation: A genus of ceratodont fishes, established for the living representative of the family, the barramunda, N. forsteri or Ceratodus forsteri.

neoclassic.explanation: Belonging to, or designating, the modern revival or adaptation of classical, esp. Greco-Roman, style, taste and manner of work in architecture, arts, literature, etc.
characteristic of a revival of an earlier classical style

neoclassical.explanation: Of pertaining to a style of architecture based on classical models, especially such a style of the 18th century.
characteristic of a revival of an earlier classical style

neoclassicism.explanation: A revival of classical aesthetics and forms, especially.
A revival in literature in the late 1600s and 1700s, characterized by a regard for the classical ideals of reason, form, and restraint.
A revival in the 1700s and 1800s in architecture and art, especially in the decorative arts, characterized by order, symmetry, and simplicity of style.
A movement in music lasting roughly from 1915 to 1940 that sought to avoid subjective emotionalism and to return to the style of the pre-Romantic composers.
Any of various intellectual movements that embrace a set of traditional principles regarded as fundamental or authoritative.
The character of being neoclassic; revival of classic style in art or literature.
a revival of the classical Greek and Roman style in art or literature.
any of several movements in the arts , architecture , literature and music that revived forms from earlier centuries
revival of a classical style (in art or literature or architecture or music) but from a new perspective or with a new motivation

neocolonial.explanation: Of or pertaining to, or based on, neocolonialism

neocolonialism.explanation: The policy or practice of a wealthy or powerful nation in extending its influence into a less developed one, especially in exploiting that nation's resources.

Control by a powerful country of its former colonies (or other less developed countries) by economic pressures. In contrast to colonialism , in which one country controls another territory by military force.
The control or domination by a powerful country over weaker ones (especially former colonies ) by the use of economic pressure , political suppression and cultural dominance .
control by a powerful country of its former colonies (or other less developed countries) by economic pressures

neocolonialist.explanation: Of or relating to neocolonialism ; neocolonial .

neocomian.explanation: In geology , the name given to the lower division of the Cretaceous system.
Of or pertaining to the lower greensand.
A term applied to the lowest deposits of the Cretaceous or chalk formation of Europe, being the lower greensand.

neoconservative.explanation: a conservative who subscribes to neoconservatism

neocortex.explanation: The dorsal region of the cerebral cortex, especially large in primates, thought to have evolved more recently than other parts of the brain.

The cortical part of the neencephalon; the most recently evolved part of the cerebral cortex of the brain of higher animals, and the site of most of the higher brain functions; called also neopallium .
The top layer of the cerebral hemispheres in the brain of mammals; part of cerebral cortex .
the cortical part of the neencephalon

neocortical.explanation: Of or pertaining to the neocortex.
Of or pertaining to the neocortex
of or relating to the neocortex of the cerebrum

neocosmic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the universe in its present state; specifically, pertaining to the races of men known to history.
Of or relating to the universe in its present state; specifically, relating to the races of human beings known to history .

neocracy.explanation: Government by new or inexperienced officials; the rule or supremacy of upstarts.
Government by new or inexperienced hands; upstart rule; raw or untried officials.
Government by the new or inexperienced .

neocriticism.explanation: The form of Neo-Kantianism developed by French idealists, following C. Renouvier. It rejects the noumena of Kant, restricting knowledge to phenomena as constituted by a priori categories.

neodamode.explanation: In ancient Sparta, a person newly admitted to citizenship; a newly enfranchised helot.
In ancient Sparta, one of those Helots who were freed by the state in reward for military service.
A Helot who was freed from the Spartan army after serving as a hoplite

neodymium.explanation: A bright, silvery, reactive rare-earth element, found in monazite and bastnaesite and used for coloring glass, for doping laser glass and crystals, and in materials with strong, permanent magnetic properties that make them useful for computer and audio equipment. Atomic number 60; atomic weight 144.24; melting point 1,016°C; boiling point 3,074°C; specific gravity 7.008; valence 3. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
An element which occurs in cerite, albanite, and other comparatively rare minerals.
The chemical element of atomic number 60, one of the rare earth elements. Symbol Nd. Atomic weight 144.27.
A metallic chemical element (symbol Nd) with an atomic number of 60.
a yellow trivalent metallic element of the rare earth group; occurs in monazite and bastnasite in association with cerium and lanthanum and praseodymium

neoexpressionism.explanation: an art movement based on expressionism; developed in 1980s in Europe and United States; crudely drawn garish paintings

neofascism.explanation: A movement inspired by the tenets and methods of fascism or Nazism.
A right-wing political movement inspired by fascism , especially by that of fascist Italy.

neofiber.explanation: A genus of American muskrats, of the family Muridæ and subfamily Arvicolinæ , resembling Fiber , but having the tail cylindric. N. alleni , lately discovered in Florida, is the only species known.

neogaean.explanation: Neogæa; indigenous to or autochthonous in the New World; American.
Of or pertaining to the New World, or Western Hemisphere.
Of or relating to the New World , or Western Hemisphere .

neogamy.explanation: In zoology , the very precocious conjugation of two gregarines, in some instances, as in Cystobia irregularis , where it takes place at the beginning of the life-cycle, when the two parasites have hardly advanced beyond the sporozoite stage.

neogenesis.explanation: A new genesis or begetting; new production. See the extract. The term neogenesis was first used to explain this sudden origin of new forms from old-established species, if I am not mistaken, by my friend and colleague Professor Paolo Mantegazza, many years ago; it has been since used, more or less in the same sense, by the late Professor Cope and by others.

neogenetic.explanation: biology , making its appearance during individual development or ontogeny.

neogrammarian.explanation: An adherent of a school of students of comparative Indo-European grammar (since about 1875), who insist especially upon the importance and strictness of the laws of phonetic change.
One of a group of philologists who apply phonetic laws more widely and strictly than was formerly done, and who maintain that these laws admit of no real exceptions.

neohipparion.explanation: A genus of three-toed horses occurring in the Miocene deposits of North America, and distinguished from the European Pliocene genus Hipparion by the structure of the teeth, the more slender construction of the long bones of the limbs and feet, and the relatively greater reduction of the lateral digits.

neoimpressionism.explanation: A movement in late 19th-century painting led by Georges Seurat that was stricter and more formal than impressionism in composition and employed pointillism as a technique.

A theory or practice which is a further development, on more rigorously scientific lines, of the theory and practice of Impressionism, originated by George Seurat (1859-91), and carried on by Paul Signac (1863- -) and others. Its method is marked by the laying of pure primary colors in minute dots upon a white ground, any given line being produced by a variation in the proportionate quantity of the primary colors employed. This method is also known as Pointillism (stippling).
A genre of French impressionist art that used pointillism to achieve a more formal composition

neolith.explanation: A stone implement of the Neolithic Period.
A stone implement, or weapon, of the Neolithic period; also a person living in that period. See Neolithic .
a stone tool from the Neolithic Age

neologian.explanation: One who introduces needless innovations in language or thought: specifically applied to a modern school of rationalistic interpreters of Scripture. See neology .

neologic.explanation: Of or pertaining to neology; employing new words; of the nature of, or containing, new words or new doctrines.

neologism.explanation: A new word, expression, or usage.
The creation or use of new words or senses.
The invention of new words regarded as a symptom of certain psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia.
A new doctrine or a new interpretation of scripture.
A new word or phrase, or a new use of a word.
The use of new words, or of old words in new senses.
The introduction of new words, or the use of old words in a new sense.
A new word, phrase, or expression.
A word or phrase which has recently been coined; a new word or phrase.
( uncountable ) The act or instance of coining, or uttering a new word.
The newly coined, meaningless words or phrases of someone with a psychosis , usually schizophrenia .
a newly invented word or phrase
the act of inventing a word or phrase

neologist.explanation: One who introduces new words or phrases into a language.
One who introduces new words or new senses of old words into a language.
An innovator in any doctrine or system of belief, especially in theology; one who introduces or holds doctrines subversive of supernatural or revealed religion; a rationalist, so-called.
One who coins a new word or new words
An innovator in any doctrine or system of belief, especially in theology .
a lexicographer of new words and expressions

neologistic.explanation: Of or pertaining to neology; neological.

neologization.explanation: The act of neologizing, in any sense of that word.
The act or process of neologizing.
The act or process of neologizing ; the creation of new forms.

neologize.explanation: To introduce or use new words or terms or new uses of old words.
To introduce innovations in doctrine, esp. in theological doctrine.

neologized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of neologize .

neology.explanation: Innovation in language; the introduction of new words or new senses of old words.
The invention or introduction of new ideas or views.
The introduction of a new word, or of words or significations, into a language.
The study or art of neologizing (creating new words).
The act of introducing a new word into a language
The holding of novel or rational religious views
the act of inventing a word or phrase
a newly invented word or phrase

neomenia.explanation: The time of new moon; the beginning of the month.
In antiquity , a festival held at the time of the new moon.
A genus of animals of disputed characters and affinities, type of a family Neomeniidæ.
The time of the new moon; the beginning of the month in the lunar calendar.
The time of the new moon ; the beginning of the month in the lunar calendar .

neomenian.explanation: Neomenia , or having their characters; neomenioid.
An animal of the genus Neomenia.

neomorph.explanation: In biology , a part or organ, or a modification of a part or organ, which has recently been generated or acquired.
A structure, part, or organ developed independently, that is, not derived from a similar structure, part, or organ, in a preexisting form.
a gain of function mutation that causes novel gene function.

neomorphism.explanation: A new formation; development of a new or different form.

neomycin.explanation: A broad-spectrum antibiotic produced from strains of the actinomycete Streptomyces fradiae and used especially in the form of its sulfate as an intestinal antiseptic in surgery.
A broad-spectrum aminoglycoside antibiotic that is found in many topical medications
an antibiotic obtained from an actinomycete and used (as a sulphate under the trade name Neobiotic) as an intestinal antiseptic in surgery

neomylodon.explanation: A genus of gigantic extinct ground-sloths whose remains have been found in the caverns of Patagonia in a condition and association which indicate that the animal is but recently extinct and has been a contemporary of the existing fauna of the region, including man.

neon.explanation: A rare, inert gaseous element occurring in the atmosphere to the extent of 18 parts per million and obtained by fractional distillation of liquid air. It is colorless but glows reddish orange in an electric discharge and is used in lasers, as a cryogen, and in cathode-ray tubes and other display devices. Atomic number 10; atomic weight 20.180; melting point −248.59°C; boiling point −246.08°C. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
Electric signage made with neon lights.
An extremely bright shade of a color.
Of, relating to, or containing neon.
Of or relating to a form of lighting used especially on advertising signs and consisting of glass tubes filled with neon or other gases that emit colored light when subjected to an electric current.
An elementary substance occurring in gaseous form in the earth's atmosphere: atomic weight, 20.
The chemical element (symbol Ne) with an atomic number of 10.
A form or sample of the element.
a colorless odorless gaseous element that give a red glow in a vacuum tube; one of the six inert gasses; occurs in the air in small amounts

neonatal.explanation: Of or relating to a newborn infant or to the first 28 days of an infant's life.
of or pertaining to a neonate.
Of or pertaining to the period of time immediately following birth, or to the newborn .
relating to or affecting the infant during the first month after birth

neonate.explanation: A newborn infant, especially one less than four weeks old.
A newborn child, especially one less than one month old.
A newborn infant ; recently born baby.
a baby from birth to four weeks

neonatology.explanation: The branch of pediatrics that deals with the diseases and care of newborn infants.
The branch of medicine that deals with newborn infants , especially the ill or premature newborn infant.
that branch of pediatric medicine concerned with the newborn; the diagnosis and treatment of neonates

neonomian.explanation: One who holds that the old or Mosaic law is abolished and that the gospel is a new law. See Neonomianism .
One who advocates adheres to new laws; esp. one who holds or believes that the gospel is a new law.
Of or pertaining to the Neonomians, or in accordance with their doctrines.

neonomianism.explanation: The doctrine that the gospel is a new law, and that faith and a partial obedience are accepted in place of the perfect obedience of the old moral law.
The doctrines or belief of the neonomians.

neons.explanation: Plural form of neon (the fish, neon tetras )

neontology.explanation: The zoölogy of extant as distinguished from extinct animals; the science of living animals: opposed to paleontology.
the study of organisms living in the current era

neopaganism.explanation: A revival or reproduction of paganism.

neopallium.explanation: That area of the cortex of the brain which lies between the hippocampus and the pyriform lobe.
the cortical part of the neencephalon

neophilism.explanation: A love of novelty; a preference, sometimes amounting to an insane desire, for what is new.

neophobia.explanation: Fear of novelty; abhorrence of what is new or unaccustomed; dislike of innovation.
The fear or dislike of new things.

neophobic.explanation: Afflicted by neophobia ; fearing or disliking what is new .

neophron.explanation: A genus of Old World vultures, technically characterized by the horizontal nostrils, and typified by the Egyptian vulture. Neophron percnopterus.

neophyte.explanation: A recent convert to a belief; a proselyte.
A novice of a religious order or congregation.
A new convert; one newly initiated.
In the Roman Catholic Church , a converted heathen, heretic, etc.
Occasionally in the Roman Catholic Church , a novice.
A tiro; a beginner in learning.
Synonyms Proselyte, Apostate , etc. See convert .

A new convert or proselyte; -- a name given by the early Christians, and still given by the Roman Catholics, to such as have recently embraced the Christian faith, and been admitted to baptism, esp. to converts from heathenism or Judaism.
A novice; a tyro; a beginner in anything.
A novice (recent convert), a new convert or proselyte , a new monk .

A name given by the early Christians, and still given by the Roman Catholics , to those who have recently embraced the Christian faith, and been admitted to baptism, especially those converts from heathenism or Judaism .
A plant species recently introduced to an area (in contrast to archaeophyte, a long-established introduced species).
a new convert being taught the principles of Christianity by a catechist
any new participant in some activity
a plant that is found in an area where it had not been recorded previously

neophytism.explanation: The condition of a neophyte or novice.

neoplasm.explanation: An abnormal new growth of tissue in animals or plants; a tumor.
A new growth or true tumor; a morbid growth more or less distinct histologically from the tissue in which it occurs.
A new formation or tissue, the product of morbid action.
An abnormal new growth of disorganized tissue in animals or plants .
an abnormal new mass of tissue that serves no purpose

neoplastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to neoplasty, or neoplasia.
of or relating to a neoplasm , neoplasty or neoplasia
of or related to or having the properties of a neoplasm

neoplasticism.explanation: A style of abstract painting , developed by Piet Mondrian, that used only vertical and horizontal lines with the spaces filled in black, white, grey, and primary colours

neoplasticist.explanation: An artist working in the style of neoplasticism .

neoplasty.explanation: Surgical measures adapted to the formation of new parts.
Restoration of a part by granulation, adhesive inflammation, or autoplasty.
Restoration of a part by granulation , adhesive inflammation , or autoplasty .

neoplatonic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Neoplatonism or the Neoplatonists.

neoplatonism.explanation: A system of philosophical and religious doctrines and principles which originated in Alexandria with Ammonius Saccas in the third century, and was developed by Plotinus, Porphyry, Iamblichus, Hypatia, Proclus, and others in the third, fourth, and fifth centuries.

A pantheistic eclectic school of philosophy, of which Plotinus was the chief (a. d. 205-270), and which sought to reconcile the Platonic and Aristotelian systems with Oriental theosophy. It tended to mysticism and theurgy, and was the last product of Greek philosophy.

a system of philosophical and theological doctrines composed of elements of Platonism and Aristotelianism and oriental mysticism; its most distinctive doctrine holds that the first principle and source of reality transcends being and thought and is naturally unknowable

neoplatonist.explanation: A believer in the doctrines or principles of Neoplatonism.
One who held to Neoplatonism; a member of the Neoplatonic school.

neoprene.explanation: A synthetic rubber produced by polymerization of chloroprene and used in weather-resistant products, adhesives, shoe soles, sportswear, paints, and rocket fuels.

A synthetic rubber , a polymer of chloroprene , commonly used in wetsuits , laptop sleeves, orthopedic braces, electrical insulation, liquid and sheet-applied elastomeric membranes and flashings , car fan belts, etc.
a synthetic rubber that is resistant to oils and aging; used in waterproof products

neorama.explanation: A panorama representing the interior of a large building, in which the spectator appears to be placed.
A panorama of the interior of a building, seen from within.
A panorama of the interior of a building , seen from within .

neorealism.explanation: A movement in art , literature and (especially in Italy) cinema , shortly after the Second World War , that concentrated on real life

neornithes.explanation: One of two main divisions of birds, comprising all save the extinct Archæopteryx and its immediate, but as yet unknown, relatives: contrasted with Archæornithes .

neosalvarsan.explanation: An organoarsenic compound that is used in the treatment of syphilis

neosorex.explanation: A genus of aquatic fringe-footed American shrews, with 32 teeth, long close-haired tail, and the feet not webbed.

neosporidia.explanation: A group of Sporozoa in which growth and reproduction go on at the same time. It includes the Myxosporidia and Sarcosporidia. Contrasted with Telosporidia. Schaudinn .

neossine.explanation: The substance of which edible bird's-nests are partly composed; the inspissated saliva of certain swifts of the genus Collocalia.
The substance constituting the edible bird's nest.
The substance constituting the edible bird's nest.

neossology.explanation: The study of young birds; that part of ornithology which relates to incubation, rearing of the young, etc. Compare caliology .

neossoptile.explanation: One of the feathers which form the covering of a newly-hatched bird, resembling but distinct from the down of an adult bird. Neossoptiles are distinguished by having a very short calamus; a very short rhachis, or none at all; practical absence of cilia; long slender rami; and no aftershaft, save in the emu. The term is correlative with mesoptile and teleoptile .

neostigmine.explanation: Either of two related white crystalline compounds, C 12 H 19 BrN 2 O 2 or C 13 H 22 N 2 O 6 S, that opposes the action of acetylcholinesterase and is used primarily to treat myasthenia gravis and to counteract muscle atony and muscle relaxants.
A parasympathomimetic , a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor .
a cholinergic drug (trade name Prostigmin) used to treat some ophthalmic conditions and to treat myasthenia gravis

neostriatum.explanation: That part of the corpus striatum that is more recently developed

neostyle.explanation: A duplicating-machine constructed on the principle of the press.

neotenic.explanation: of or relating to or characterized by neoteny

neotenous.explanation: Exhibiting retention of juvenile characteristics in the adult .
of or relating to or characterized by neoteny

neoteny.explanation: The retention of juvenile characteristics in the adults of a species, as among certain amphibians.
The attainment of sexual maturity and subsequent reproduction by an organism still in its larval stage.
In biology : The reversion of a phylum to a modified embryonic condition.

The retention by an organism of larval or juvenile characters beyond the time characteristic of other members of the group to which it belongs. This may be partial, as in the case of some toads and frogs, whose young pass the winter in the tadpole condition, or total, as in some salamanders that retain their external gills when adult. Also neotenia .
The retention of juvenile characteristics in the adult .
The sexual maturity of an organism still in its larval stage .
an evolutionary trend to be born earlier so that development is cut off at an earlier stage and juvenile characteristics are retained in adults of the species

neoteric.explanation: One of modern times; a modern.
A modern author (especially as opposed to a classical writer).
Someone with new or modern ideas.

neoterism.explanation: Innovation; specifically, the introduction of new words or phrases into a language; neologism.
A word or phrase so introduced; a neologism.
An innovation or novelty; a neoteric word or phrase.
An innovation or novelty; a neoteric word or phrase.

neoterist.explanation: One who invents new words or expressions; an innovator in language; a neologist.
One who introduces new words or phrases; a neologist.
One who introduces new words or phrases .

neoterize.explanation: To innovate; to coin or introduce new words.
to neologize , to coin as a new word.

neotoma.explanation: A genus of very large sigmodont Murinæ peculiar to North America; the wood-rats.

neotraditionalist.explanation: A follower or adherent of neotraditionalism.

neotragus.explanation: A genus of pygmy antelopes of Africa; the steinboks.

neotropical.explanation: zoögeog. , belonging to that division of the New World which is not Nearctic: specifically applied by Sclater to one of six prime divisions of the earth's surface, and including all of America which is south of the Nearctic region.
Belonging to, or designating, a region of the earth's surface which comprises most of South America, the Antilles, and tropical North America.
Occurring in tropical America, i.e. the tropics of "the new world".

neotype.explanation: A biological specimen or other element that is selected as the type specimen when the holotype, lectotype, and any syntypes or paratypes have been lost or destroyed.
A specimen identified with some described and. named species, selected as a standard of reference where the original type is lost or damaged beyond recognition, or is not available.
A new specimen used to replace a lost holotype

neovitalism.explanation: In physiology : The doctrine or opinion that the distinctive activities of living beings cannot completely be accounted for as the resultants of the physical and chemical constitution of their bodies and of their movements, according to the principles of mechanics.

The doctrine or opinion that the distinctive activities of living beings are different in kind from those of inorganic bodies, and that they are due to a different kind of energy from any that is made known by the study of the inorganic universe: because knowledge of the physics and chemistry of their bodies, while it may make it possible to foresee or predict their actions, does not reveal what brings them about and makes them to be what they are. Since the aim of the concrete sciences is to predict the consequences of given antecedents and not to discover who or what makes them to be, there is no difference between physics and physiology in this respect.

In biology , the doctrine or opinion that the generation of uew beings from eggs and parts of eggs, and the regeneration or replacement of parts that have been lost, cannot be explained or understood as the mechanical resultants of the conditions under which they take place, because they bring about or restore that due subordination and interadjustment of parts which is necessary for establishing or restoring the coördination and unity of the whole: although inability to account for these processes by means of the history of the individual does not show that they may not be the intelligible consequences, direct or indirect, of ancestral history.

neowashingtonia.explanation: A genus of palms. See Washingtonia , 2.

neoza.explanation: A tree, Rinus Gerardiana , of the Himalayas. Its sseds are edible.

neozoic.explanation: More recent than the Paleozoic, -- that is, including the Mesozoic and Cenozoic.

nep.explanation: A knob, swelling, protuberance, or knot which exists in imperfect cotton-fibers as a result either of unsymmetrical growth or of operations (principally ginning) to which the cotton is subjected preparatory to carding or combing.

nepenthaceous.explanation: Nepenthaceæ , a family of insectivorous plants.

nepenthe.explanation: A drug mentioned in the Odyssey as a remedy for grief.
Something that induces forgetfulness of sorrow or eases pain.
A drug used by the ancients to give relief from pain and sorrow; -- by some supposed to have been opium or hasheesh. Hence, anything soothing and comforting.

nepenthes.explanation: A magic potion, mentioned by ancient writers, which was supposed to make persons forget their sorrows and misfortunes.
A genus of pitcher-plants, comprising 31 species, and constituting the order Nepenthaceœ , found especially in the Malay archipelago.

A genus of climbing plants found in tropical areas of India, Malaya, Australia, etc., which have the leaves prolonged into a kind of stout tendril terminating in a pitcherlike appendage, whence the plants are often called pitcher plants and monkey-cups . There are about thirty species, of which the best known is Nepenthes distillatoria . See Pitcher plant .
A drug referred to in Homer's Odyssey as bringing relief from anxiety or grief; hence, any substance seen as bringing welcome forgetfulness or relief .
A Southeast Asian plant of the genus Nepenthes.

neper.explanation: A unit of attenuation used in transmission line theory; equivalent to 8.686 dB.

nepeta.explanation: Any plant of the genus Nepeta of flowering plants , including catnip and ground ivy .

nephalism.explanation: The principles or practice of those who abstain from spirituous liquors; total abstinence; teetotalism.
The practice of abstaining completely from the drinking of alcohol ; teetotalism

nephalist.explanation: One who practises or advocates nephalism, or total abstinence from intoxicating drink; a teetotaler.
One who advocates or practices nephalism.
One who practises nephalism ; a teetotaller

nephele.explanation: In the Gr. Ch. , the outermost eucharistic veil: same as air , 7.

nepheline.explanation: A mineral of sodium-aluminum or potassium-aluminum silicate, occurring worldwide in igneous rocks and used in the manufacture of ceramics and enamels.

A mineral occuring at Vesuvius, in glassy hexagonal crystals; also elsewhere, in grayish or greenish masses having a greasy luster, as the variety elæolite. It is a silicate of aluminia, soda, and potash.

A feldspathoid mineral of silica -poor igneous , plutonic and volcanic rocks . Chemically, nepheline is a plagioclase feldspar with insufficient silica to satisfy the chemical bonds. Because of the unfilled bonds, nepheline weathers rapidly and can only be seen as inclusions in freshly broken rock.
a whitish mineral consisting of sodium aluminum silicate or potassium aluminum silicate in crystalline form; used in the manufacture of ceramics and enamels

nephelinite.explanation: An igneous rock consisting chiefly of pyroxene and nepheline.
The name given by Rosenbusch to what had previously been generally designated us “nephelin-dolerite.” The difference between this rock and nephelin-basalt is exceedingly slight. See nephelin-basalt .
a dark, finely crystalline rock of volcanic origin, being a mixture of nepheline and pyroxene
an igneous rock consisting of nepheline and pyroxene

nephelite.explanation: a whitish mineral consisting of sodium aluminum silicate or potassium aluminum silicate in crystalline form; used in the manufacture of ceramics and enamels

nephelium.explanation: A genus of dicotyledonous trees of the polypetalous order Sapindaceæ and the tribe Sapindeæ known by the regular cup-shaped five-toothed calyx, indehiscent warty fruit, and long projecting stamens.
a genus of dicotyledonous trees of the family Sapindaceae that are native to Asia and Australia

nephelometer.explanation: An apparatus that is used to measure the size and concentration of particles in a liquid by analysis of light scattered by the liquid.
A proposed instrument which will make a continuous record of the proportion of cloudiness of the sky. No such instrument has yet been constructed.

In chem. , an instrument for estimating the quantity of a solid substance suspended, in very small proportion and in a very finely divided state, in a liquid, as in the case of one or two milligrams of silver chlorid in a liter of water.
An instrument for measuring or registering the amount of cloudiness.

An instrument which measures the degree to which liquid suspensions scatter light, and by inference, the concentration of scattering particles in the suspension. It is used for various purposes, such as to estimate the number of bacteria in suspension in a liquid.
An instrument for measuring various aspects of the suspended particles in a fluid ; especially in a colloid .

nephelometry.explanation: The art of measuring, observing, or studying the general cloudiness of the sky.
The art of measuring the size, growth, and other changes of a particular cloud.
The application of the photogrammeter to cloud-work.
The measurement of the concentration of a solution , suspension or dispersion based upon its light-scattering properties.
Technique used to determine levels of antibodies or antigens in a suspension based up its light-scattering properties.

nepheloscope.explanation: An apparatus devised by Espy for illustrating the formation of cloud.

nephew.explanation: A son of one's brother or sister or of the brother or sister of one's spouse.
A grandchild; sometimes, a more remote lineal descendant.
The son of one's brother or sister. This is now the usual meaning. Sometimes, in the interpretation of wills, the word is understood as including also ‘grandnephew.’
A grandson or grandchild, or remoter lineal descendant.
The son of a brother or a sister, or of a brother-in-law or sister-in-law.
A son of one's sibling , brother-in-law , or sister-in-law ; either a son of one's brother ( fraternal nephew ) or a son of one's sister ( sororal nephew ).
a son of your brother or sister

nephila.explanation: A genus of spinning-spiders of the family Epeiridæ , having a long cylindrical abdomen. N. plumipes is well known and abundant in the southern United States.

nephite.explanation: According to the Book of Mormon, one of the descendants of Nephi, who, with his brothers and his father Lehi, of the tribe of Joseph, fled from Jerusalem to America.

nephogram.explanation: A photograph of a cloud or clouds.

nephology.explanation: The branch of meteorology that deals with clouds.
That part of meteorology which treats of clouds.
The branch of meteorology that studies clouds .
the branch of meteorology that studies clouds and cloud formation

nephoscope.explanation: An instrument used in determining the apparent velocity and the direction of motion of clouds.
An instrument for observing the clouds and their velocity.
An instrument for determining the direction of and angular velocity of clouds .
a measuring instrument that uses a grid for measuring the altitude, direction, and velocity of movement of clouds

nephralgia.explanation: In pathology , pain in the kidneys; renal neuralgia.
Neuralgia of the kidneys; a disease characterized by pain in the region of the kidneys without any structural lesion of the latter.
pain in the kidney (usually felt in the loins)

nephrectasia.explanation: Dilatation of the pelvis of the kidney, leading to the formation of a cystic kidney.

nephrectomized.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of nephrectomize .

nephrectomy.explanation: In surgery , excision of a kidney.
the surgical removal of a kidney

nephric.explanation: Relating to or connected with a kidney.
Relating to or connected with a kidney .

nephridial.explanation: Of or pertaining to a nephridium.
Of or pertaining to a nephridium

nephridiopore.explanation: An opening of a nephridium to the exterior.
The external opening of a nephridium

nephridium.explanation: A tubular excretory organ in many invertebrates, such as mollusks and earthworms.
The excretory organ of a vertebrate embryo from which the kidney develops.
The sexual or renal organ of mollusks, corresponding to the kidneys of the vertebrates, having an excretory and depurative office; the so-called organ of Bojanus.
A segmental tubule; one of the tubules of the primitive urinogenital organs; a segmental organ. See Illust. under loeven's larva .
a tubular excretory organ in some invertebrates
the embryonic excretory organ that develops into the kidney

nephrism.explanation: A pathological condition characterized by serious disease of the kidneys.

nephrite.explanation: A white to dark green variety of jade, chiefly a metasilicate of iron, calcium, and magnesium.
A tough compact variety of amphibole (tremolite or actinolite), of a leek-green color, often found in rolled pieces: jade. It was formerly worn as a remedy for diseases of the kidneys. See jade .

A hard compact mineral, of a dark green color, formerly worn as a remedy for diseases of the kidneys, whence its name; kidney stone; a kind of jade. It varies in color from white to dark green. It is the more common and less valuable variety of jade, the other being jadeite. Large deposits are found in Australia. Called also nephritic stone . See also jade .
A semi-precious stone, one of the two types of stone commonly referred to as jade , (the other being jadeite ).
an amphibole mineral consisting of calcium magnesium silicate in monoclinic crystalline form; a source of jade that is less valuable than from jadeite; once believed to cure kidney disorders

nephritic.explanation: Of or relating to the kidneys; renal.
Of, relating to, or affected with nephritis.
A medicine adapted to relieve or cure diseases of the kidneys, particularly gravel or stone in the bladder.
A medicine adapted to relieve or cure disease of the kidneys.
Of or pertaining to the kidneys or urinary organs; renal.
Affected with a disease of the kidneys.
Relieving disorders of the kidneys; affecting the kidneys.
Of or relating to the kidneys .
Of, relating to, or affected with nephritis .
of or relating to the kidneys

nephritis.explanation: Any of various acute or chronic inflammations of the kidneys, such as Bright's disease.
In pathology , inflammation of the kidneys. See Bright's disease , under disease.

nephrocele.explanation: In pathology , hernia of the kidney.
In embryology , the cavity of the pronephric and mesonephric tubule considered as an extension of the cœloma or true body-cavity of the embryo.

nephrocystitis.explanation: Inflammation of both the kidney and the bladder.

nephrocyte.explanation: An excretory cell, with fibrillar or vacuolated cytoplasm, which contains masses of waste products. Such cells occur in the track of the blood-currents in the Crustacea.
a specialized cell , especially in arthropods , whose function involves the accumulation or formation of waste or excretory products

nephrodium.explanation: An extensive genus of cosmopolitan polypodiaceous aspidioid ferns with cordate-reniform indusia.

nephrogenic.explanation: that forms the tissues of the kidney

nephrogenous.explanation: Able to develop into kidney tissue.

nephrogonaduct.explanation: The nephridium of a mollusk when it serves as a gonaduct. See idiogonaduct .

nephroid.explanation: In mathematics , a curve of the sixth order with one triple and one single crunode, the polar equation being r = a (1 + 2 sin ½θ ).

nephrolepis.explanation: A genus of polypodiaceous ferns of the tribe Aspidicæ , having pinnate fronds with the pinnæ articulated at the base and often very deciduons in the dried plant.
small genus of tropical ferns; sometimes placed in Polypodiaceae

nephrolith.explanation: a calculus formed in the kidney

nephrolithic.explanation: medicine , relating to calculus in the kidney.
Of or pertaining to kidney stones, or renal calculi.
Of or relating to gravel , or renal calculi .

nephrolithotomy.explanation: In surgery , the removal of a calculus from the kidney by an incision.
The removal of a renal calculus by incision into the kidney

nephrologist.explanation: One who is versed in nephrology.
a physician whose speciality is nephrology

nephrology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and disorders of the kidneys.
Scientific knowledge or investigation of the kidney.
A treatise on, or the science which treats of, the kidneys, and their structure and functions.
The branch of medicine that deals with the function and diseases of the kidneys .
the branch of medicine concerned with the kidney - its development and anatomy and physiology and disorders

nephrolysis.explanation: Destruction of the cells of the kidney by a toxin or other morbid agent in the blood.
The loosening or destruction of pathological adhesions which bind the kidney to the surrounding tissues.

nephromegaly.explanation: Enlargement of one or both kidneys.
The process whereby a kidney or both kidneys become enlarged .

nephromere.explanation: That part of the mesoderm which forms the kidneys.

nephron.explanation: The functional excretory unit of the vertebrate kidney that regulates the amount of water in the body and filters wastes from the blood to produce urine.
The basic structural and functional unit of the kidney , which filters the blood in order to regulate chemical concentrations, and thereby produces urine .
any of the small tubules that are the excretory units of the vertebrate kidney

nephropathy.explanation: A disease or abnormality of the kidney.
Damage to, disease of, or abnormality of the kidneys .

nephropexy.explanation: A surgical operation for fixing a floating kidney in position.
suspension or fixation of the kidney

nephrops.explanation: A genus of long-tailed ten-footed crustaceans of the family Homaridæ: so called from the nephroid eyes, N. norvegicus , known as the Norway lobster, is found on the Atlantic coasts of Europe, and has commercial value.

nephroptosis.explanation: Downward displacement of the kidney; floating or wandering kidney.

nephrorrhaphy.explanation: The stitching of a (movable) kidney to the lumbar abdominal parietes.

nephrosclerosis.explanation: kidney disease that is usually associated with hypertension; sclerosis of the renal arterioles reduces blood flow that can lead to kidney failure and heart failure

nephrosis.explanation: A disease of the kidneys marked by degenerative lesions, especially of the winding uriniferous tubules.
A non-inflammatory disease of the kidneys that is characterised by the leaking of blood protein into the urine , swelling or oedema , and degenerative lesions .

a syndrome characterized by edema and large amounts of protein in the urine and usually increased blood cholesterol; usually associated with glomerulonephritis or with a complication of various systemic diseases

nephrostome.explanation: One of the ciliated infundibular orifices of a primitive kidney. See pronephron .
The funnel-shaped opening of a nephridium into the body cavity.
The funnel -shaped opening of a nephridium into the body cavity .

nephrotic.explanation: Pertaining to, resembling or caused by nephrosis .

nephrotome.explanation: A segmental portion of the mesoblast, which, in the vertebrate, gives rise to the embryonic kidneys, that is, the pronephros and mesonephros.

nephrotomy.explanation: In surgery , the operation of incising the kidney, as for the extraction of a calculus.
Extraction of stone from the kidney by cutting.
the surgical procedure of cutting, or making an incision in a kidney
incision into a kidney (usually to remove a kidney stone)

nephrotoxic.explanation: that is poisonous to kidney tissue

nephrotoxicity.explanation: The state or condition of being nephrotoxic .

nephrotoxin.explanation: A cytotoxin, resulting on immunization with renal epithelial cells.
any toxin that affects the kidneys

nephrotyphoid.explanation: Acute inflammation of the kidneys associated with the presence of typhoid bacilli.

nephrotyphus.explanation: Severe inflammation of the kidneys complicating typhus fever.

nepidae.explanation: A natural family of water scorpions.

nepionic.explanation: entomology , larval: contrasted with ne anic , ephebic , 2, and gerontic .

nepotal.explanation: Of or relating to a nephew.
Of or relating to a nephew .

nepotism.explanation: Favoritism shown or patronage granted to relatives, as in business.
Favoritism shown to nephews and other relatives; patronage bestowed in consideration of family relationship and not of merit.
Undue attachment to relations; favoritism shown to members of one's family; bestowal of patronage in consideration of relationship, rather than of merit or of legal claim.
The favoring of relatives or personal friends because of their relationship rather than because of their abilities.
favoritism shown to relatives or close friends by those in power (as by giving them jobs)

nepotist.explanation: One who practices or engages in nepotism .
a powerful person who shows favoritism to relatives or close friends

nepotistic.explanation: Of or pertaining to nepotism ; favoring relatives because of their relationship rather than their abilities.

neptunist.explanation: In geology , an advocate of or believer in the Neptunian theory; an opponent of the Vulcanists.

neptunium.explanation: A silvery, metallic, naturally radioactive element, atomic number 93, the first of the transuranium elements. Its longest-lived isotope is Np-237 with a half-life of 2.1 million years. Found in trace quantities in uranium ores, it is produced synthetically by nuclear reactions. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
In chem. , a supposed new element announced by Hermann in 1877 as present in columbite and ferro-ilmenite. Its existence has not been confirmed.
A radioactive metallic element of atomic number 93, produced in nuclear reactors from Plutonium or Uranium. Symbol Np; The atomic weight of the most stable isotope is 237.0482.
The transuranic chemical element with atomic number 93 and symbol Np.
a radioactive transuranic metallic element; found in trace amounts in uranium ores; a by-product of the production of plutonium

neral.explanation: An oily liquid aldehyde, C 10 H 16 O, having a strong lemon odor, that is the minor constituent of naturally derived citral, used in perfumes and flavorings.

nerd.explanation: A foolish, inept, or unattractive person.
A person who is single-minded or accomplished in scientific or technical pursuits but is felt to be socially inept.
A person who is intellectual but generally introverted
One who has an intense, obsessive interest in something.
