a medusa.
A herb of the genus Urtica , which is covered with stinging , mildly poisonous hairs, causing an instant rash.
The non-stinging plant deadnettle , also in the nettle family, Urticaceae .
Loosely, anything which causes a similarly stinging rash, such as a jellyfish or sea-nettle.
Of the nettle plant and similar physical causes, to sting causing a rash in someone.
To pique , irritate , vex or provoke someone.
any of numerous plants having stinging hairs that cause skin irritation on contact (especially of the genus Urtica or family Urticaceae)
cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations
sting with or as with nettles and cause a stinging pain or sensation

nettlebird.explanation: A little bird which creeps about hedges among the nettles, as the whitethroat, Sylvia cinerea , or the blackcap, S. atricapilla.

nettled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of nettle .

nettlelike.explanation: Resembling a nettle or some aspect of one.

nettler.explanation: One who or that which stings, provokes, or irritates.

nettles.explanation: The halves of yarns in the unlaid end of a rope twisted for pointing or grafting.
Small lines used to sling hammocks under the deck beams.
Small lengths of cord attached to a sail , used to secure the excess fabric after reefing ; reef points

nettlesome.explanation: Causing irritation , annoyance , or discomfort ; bothersome , irksome .
Thorny ; difficult to deal with, especially due to being complex or tricky .

nettlewort.explanation: A plant of the nettle family ( Urticaceæ ).

nettling.explanation: A method of spinning or twisting together the ends of two ropes so as to unite them with a seamless joint.
A system of tying in pairs the yarns when they are laid on the posts in a ropewalk, in order to prevent entanglement or confusion.
A process (resembling splicing) by which two ropes are joined end to end so as to form one rope.
The process of tying together the ends of yarns in pairs, to prevent tangling.

nettly.explanation: Of, resembling, or overgrown with nettles .

netty.explanation: Like a net, or network; netted.
Like a net , or network ; netted .

network.explanation: An openwork fabric or structure in which cords, threads, or wires cross at regular intervals.
Something resembling an openwork fabric or structure in form or concept, especially.
A system of lines or channels that cross or interconnect.
A complex, interconnected group or system.
An extended group of people with similar interests or concerns who interact and remain in informal contact for mutual assistance or support.
A chain of radio or television broadcasting stations linked by wire or microwave relay.
A company that produces the programs for these stations.
A group or system of electric components and connecting circuitry designed to function in a specific manner.
A system of computers interconnected by telephone wires or other means in order to share information.
To cover with an openwork fabric or structure.
To broadcast over a radio or television network.
To interconnect as components in a group or system.
To connect (computers) into a network.
To interact or engage in informal communication with others for mutual assistance or support.

Anything formed in the manner or presenting the appearance of a net or of netting; work made of intersecting lines which form meshes or open spaces like those of a net; an openwork or reticulated fabric, structure, or appearance; interlacement; technically, anastomosis; inosculation; rete: as, a network of veins or nerves; a network of railways. See cut under latticeleaf .
Netting decorated with darned work or other needlework. Compare net embroidery , under net .
Work in metal or other tenacious and ductile material resembling a net in having large openings divided by slender solid parts. Compare fretwork .
Ornamental threadwork used as a ground for various kinds of embroidery, especially when a set of parallel threads are made into a netting by other threads worked across them with the needle.
To connect together into a network.

To take steps to make and cultivate the acquaintance of people who can be helpful to oneself, especially in finding new employment, advancing to a higher position in one's occupation, or exchanging information.
A fabric of threads, cords, or wires crossing each other at certain intervals, and knotted or secured at the crossings, thus leaving spaces or meshes between them.
Any system of lines or channels interlacing or crossing like the fabric of a net
A system of computers linked together by communications channels allowing the exchange of data between the linked computers.
A group of transmitting stations connected by communications channels that permit the same program to be broadcast simultaneously from multiple stations over a very wide area;
Any arrangement of electrical devices or elements connected together by conducting wires.
A group of buildings connected by means of transportation and communication between them, and controlled by a central organization for a common purpose.
A fabric or structure of fibrous elements attached to each other at regular intervals.
Any interconnected group or system
A directory of people maintained for their advancement
A group of affiliated television stations that broadcast common programs from a parent company.
Multiple computers and other devices connected together to share information
To interact socially for the purpose of getting connections or personal advancement .
To connect two or more computers or other computerized devices.
To interconnect a group or system .
(electronics) a system of interconnected electronic components or circuits
an interconnected system of things or people
an open fabric of string or rope or wire woven together at regular intervals
communicate with and within a group
a system of intersecting lines or channels
(broadcasting) a communication system consisting of a group of broadcasting stations that all transmit the same programs

networked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of network .
joined by a network, or to form a network

networking.explanation: Interchanging information or services, among a group; -- of persons or organizations.
the act of working using computer network.
the act of connecting computers into network.
the act of meeting new people in a business or social context.

neudeckian.explanation: In geology , noting a division of glacial time and deposits in Europe regarded by James Geikie as the third interglacial epoch, represented by marine and fresh-water deposits between the boulder-clays of the southern Baltic coast. It was preceded by the Polandian or third glacial epoch and followed by the Mecklenburgian or fourth glacial epoch.

neuk.explanation: A bend (e.g. in a coast) …the fleet, after exploring the harbours, had doubled the East Neuk, passed safely through St Andrews Bay, and entered the Firth of Tay. --Chronicles of Strathearn (1896) - Rev. John Hunter.

neumatic.explanation: music , of or pertaining to neumes.

neume.explanation: A sign used in the notation of plainsong during the Middle Ages, surviving today in transcriptions of Gregorian chants.
Modulation of the voice in singing.
A sign or character used in early medieval music to indicate a tone or a phrase.
A melodic phrase or division, sung to a single syllable, especially at the end of a clause or sentence; a sequence.
A sign used in early musical notation

neurad.explanation: Toward the neural side; -- opposed to hæmad .

neural.explanation: Of or relating to a nerve or the nervous system.
Of, relating to, or located on the same side of the body as the spinal cord; dorsal.
One of the bony plates that lie upon and fuse with the summit of the spinous process and take part in the formation of the carapace of a turtle.
physiology , done or taking place in the nerves.

relating to the nerves or nervous system; taining to, situated in the region of, or on the side with, the neural, or cerebro-spinal, axis; -- opposed to hemal . As applied to vertebrates, neural is the same as dorsal ; as applied to invertebrates it is usually the same as ventral . Cf. hemal .
the cartilaginous or bony arch on the dorsal side of the centrum of the vertebra in a segment of the spinal skeleton, usually inclosing a segment of the spinal cord.
Of, or relating to the nerves , neurons or the nervous system .
Modelled on the arrangement of neurons in the brain .
of or relating to the nervous system

neuralgia.explanation: Sharp, severe paroxysmal pain extending along a nerve or group of nerves.

A pain, corresponding frequently to the distribution of some one nerve, which is not due immediately and simply to excessive stimulation of the nerve or nerves involved by some gross or extra-nervous lesion, but to a nutritive or other molecular change in the nerves themselves or their central connections.

A disease, the chief symptom of which is a very acute pain, exacerbating or intermitting, which follows the course of a nervous branch, extends to its ramifications, and seems therefore to be seated in the nerve. It seems to be independent of any structural lesion.
An acute, severe, intermittent pain that radiates along a nerve .
acute spasmodic pain along the course of one or more nerves

neuralgy.explanation: acute spasmodic pain along the course of one or more nerves

neuraminidase.explanation: A hydrolytic enzyme that removes sialic acid from mucoproteins and is found chiefly in microorganisms of the respiratory and intestinal tracts.
An antigenic enzyme , found on the surfaces of viruses , that catalyzes the hydrolysis of terminal acylneuraminic residues from oligosaccharides , glycoproteins , and glycolipids

neurapophysial.explanation: Of or pertaining to a neurapophysis.
Of or pertaining to a neurapophysis .

neurapophysis.explanation: In anatomy , a process or part of a vertebra which, meeting its fellow in midline over the centrum of the vertebra, constitutes a neural arch and completes a neural canal.
One of the two lateral processes or elements which form the neural arch.
The dorsal process of the neural arch; neural spine; spinous process.
the structure that forms the neural arch of a vertebra

neurarthropathy.explanation: Disease of the joints involving also disease of the nerves.

neurasthenia.explanation: A psychological disorder characterized by chronic fatigue, weakness, and generalized aches and pains, formerly thought to result from exhaustion of the nervous system.
In medicine , nervous debility; nervous exhaustion.
A condition of nervous debility supposed to be dependent upon impairment in the functions of the spinal cord.
An ill-defined medical condition characterized by lassitude , fatigue , headache , and irritability , associated chiefly with emotional disturbance.

neurasthenic.explanation: A person suffering from nervous debility.
Of or pertaining to neurasthenia ; that is, tendencies of a person who has suffered a nervous breakdown.
of or relating to or suffering from neurasthenia
a person suffering a nervous breakdown

neuration.explanation: In entomology , nervature; venation, as of an insect's wing.
In anatomy , the way or mode of distribution of nerves; the system of the nerves; nervation.
The arrangement or distribution of nerves, as in the leaves of a plant or the wings of an insect; nervation; venation.
The arrangement or distribution of nerves , as in the leaves of a plant or the wings of an insect .

neuratrophia.explanation: Impaired nutrition of the nervous system, or of some part of it.

neuraxis.explanation: The central nervous system; the brain and spinal cord.
The axis of the central nervous system ; i.e. the spinal cord , rhombencephalon , mesencephalon and diencephalon

neuraxon.explanation: The axis-cylinder of the nerveor ganglion-cell, as distinguished from its other processes, the dendrites.

neurectasis.explanation: The surgical operation of stretching a nerve.

neurectomy.explanation: Surgical removal of a nerve or part of a nerve.
The operation of excising or cutting out a part of a nerve.
The surgical excision of a nerve
surgical removal of all or part of a nerve

neurectopia.explanation: Congenital displacement or accidental dislocation of a nerve.

neurenteric.explanation: Of or pertaining to both the neuron and the enteron. See Illust. of ectoderm .
Of or relating to the neuron and the enteron .

neuridine.explanation: A ptomaine (C 5 H 14 N 2 ) commonly produced in the putrefaction of proteids.
A substance isolated from the brain , later identified as spermine .

neurilemma.explanation: The sheath that is formed by a Schwann cell.
The delicate structureless sheath of a nerve-fiber; the primitive sheath; the sheath of Schwann.
The sheath of a nerve-funieulus; the perineurium.
Of the spinal cord, the pia mater.
The delicate outer sheath of a nerve fiber; the primitive sheath.
The outer membranous covering of a nerve fiber.
thin membranous sheath around a nerve fiber

neurilemmitis.explanation: In pathology , inflammation of the neurilemma.

neurility.explanation: The specific function of the nervous system—that of conducting stimuli.
The special properties and functions of the nerves; that capacity for transmitting a stimulus which belongs to nerves.
The special properties and functions of the nerves ; the nervous capacity for transmitting a stimulus .

neurine.explanation: A ptomaine, and possibly also a leucomaine, having the formula (CH 3 ) 3 .C 2 H 3 .NOH. It has decided toxic properties.
A basic substance having the formula (CH 3 ) 3 .C 2 H 4 .OH.NOH: same as choline .
The substance of which nervetissue is composed, consisting chiefly of fat and albumin containing phosphorus.
An extract made from nerve-tissue, employed therapeutically.

A poisonous organic base (a ptomaine) formed in the decomposition of protagon with boiling baryta water, and in the putrefaction of proteid matter. It was for a long time considered identical with choline, a crystalline body originally obtained from bile. Chemically, however, choline is oxyethyl-trimethyl-ammonium hydroxide, while neurine is vinyl-trimethyl-ammonium hydroxide.
A ptomaine , related to choline , formed during putrefaction of biological tissues

neurinoma.explanation: tumor (usually benign) of the sheath surrounding a nerve

neurism.explanation: Nerve force. See Vital force, under vital .
A supposed " nerve force " in vitalism .

neuristor.explanation: An electronic component that processes electrical signals in a manner modeling the behavior of neurons.

neurite.explanation: In neural. , the principal process or axis-cylinder process of a nerve-cell; a neuraxon: opposed to dendrite .
Any projection from the body of a neuron ; either a dendrite or an axon

neuritis.explanation: Inflammation of a nerve or group of nerves, characterized by pain, loss of reflexes, and atrophy of the affected muscles.
In pathology , inflammation of a nerve.
Inflammation of one or more nerves .
inflammation of a nerve accompanied by pain and sometimes loss of function

neuroactive.explanation: That act on the central nervous system

neuroanatomic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the anatomy of the nervous system
of or relating to neural tissue or the nervous system

neuroanatomical.explanation: of or relating to neural tissue or the nervous system

neuroanatomy.explanation: The branch of anatomy that deals with the nervous system.
The neural structure of a body part or organ.
The anatomy of the nervous system
The structure of the nerves of a specific organ or organism
the anatomy of the nervous system

neurobiological.explanation: Of or pertaining to neurobiology , the biological study of nerve and brain function
of or relating to the biological study of the nervous system

neurobiology.explanation: The biological study of the nervous system.
The scientific study of nerve and brain function in people and animals .
the branch of biology that deals with the anatomy and physiology and pathology of the nervous system

neuroblast.explanation: An embryonic cell from which a nerve cell develops.
One of two large cells or teloblasts which are situated at the posterior end of the body in the annelid embryo and larva and give rise to the ventral nerve-cord of the adult animal.
One of the cells in the embryonic brain and spinal cord of vertebrates. These cells are said to give rise without division to the ganglion-cells.
In arthropod embryos, certain ectodermal cells which proliferate inward from the surface to form rows of elements that become the ganglion-cells.
The embryonic cell that develops into a nerve cell
a cell from which a nerve cell develops

neuroblastic.explanation: Of or pertaining to a neuroblastoma

neuroblastoma.explanation: A malignant tumor composed of neuroblasts, originating in the autonomic nervous system or the adrenal medulla and occurring chiefly in infants and young children.
A form of cancer that affects the ganglia in various parts of the body.
malignant tumor containing embryonic nerve cells; usually metastasizes quickly

neurocentral.explanation: Between the neural arch and the centrum of a vertebra .

neurocentrum.explanation: One of a pair of vertebral elements (arcualia) lying on the dorsal face of the notochord from which the spinous process and its adjoining processes are developed. The neurocentra of Osborn correspond with the basidorsalia of Gadow, and neural arches of others.

neurochemical.explanation: Of or pertaining to neurochemistry , the study of the chemical basis of nerve and brain activity
A chemical substance that is involved in neural activity, such as a neurotransmitter
any organic substance that occurs in neural activity

neurochemist.explanation: A researcher or other professional in the field of neurochemistry

neurochemistry.explanation: The study of the chemical composition and processes of the nervous system and the effects of chemicals on it.
The branch of neuroscience concerned with the chemistry of the nervous system

neurochitin.explanation: A compound, resembling chitin, which constitutes the supporting frame-work of the nervous tissue.

neurochondrite.explanation: One of two cartilaginous elements that by growth and ossification become the neural arch of a completed vertebra. When fully formed in cartilage they are known as the neuroids : correlated with centrochondrite and pleurochondrite .

neurochord.explanation: A cord of giant fibers which, in the earthworms and their allies and in some of the thoracostracous Crustacea , accompanies the ventral nervous system, on its dorsal surface. It is commonly regarded as a degenerated nervous structure which has acquired a supporting function, serving a purpose similar to that of the notochord in vertebrates.

neurocoele.explanation: The entire hollow or system of cavities of the cerebrospinal axis.
The central canal and ventricles of the spinal cord and brain; the myelencephalic cavity.

neurocyte.explanation: Any adult nerve-cell within the central nervous system, together with its processes of whatever sort.
The cell-body of such a nerve-cell.

neurodegenerative.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or resulting in the progressive loss of nerve cells and of neurologic function

neurodendrite.explanation: One of the branching processes given off from a neurone: distinguished from the axis-cylinder process or neuraxon.

neurodendron.explanation: The arborization or terminal ramification of the processes of a nerve-cell; a neurodendrite.

neurodermatitis.explanation: dermatitis in which localized areas (especially the forearms or back of the neck or outer part of the ankle) itch persistently; cause is unknown

neurodiagnosis.explanation: Diagnosis of diseases of the nervous system.

neurodynamic.explanation: neural. , of or pertaining to nervous energy and its discharge.

neuroembryology.explanation: The study of the formation and development of the brain and nervous system in the embryo

neuroendocrine.explanation: Of, relating to, or involving the interaction between the nervous system and the hormones of the endocrine glands.
Of or pertaining to the nervous system and endocrine system together
of or relating to the nervous and endocrine systems (especially as they function together)

neuroendocrinology.explanation: The study of the interaction between the nervous system and the endocrine glands and their secretions.
The study of the interactions between the nervous system and the endocrine system .

neuroepidermal.explanation: Pertaining to, or giving rise to, the central nervous system and epidermis .

neuroepithelial.explanation: Of or relating to the neuroepithelium

neuroepithelium.explanation: The part of an embryo that develops into the nervous system
The epithelium associated with sensory organs such as the eye or nose
epithelium associated with special sense organs and containing sensory nerve endings

neurofibril.explanation: Any of the long, thin, microscopic fibrils that run through the body of a neuron and extend into the axon and dendrites.
Any of a group of microscopic fibrils through the body of a neuron that extend into the axon and dendrites

neurofibrilla.explanation: The very delicate fibrils that have been found to lie within the ganglioncells and their neuraxons and dendrites.

neurofibrillary.explanation: Of or pertaining to a neurofibril

neurofibroma.explanation: A fibroma that results from the proliferation of Schwann cells, composed of nerve fibers and connective tissue.
A tumor of a nerve, caused by circumscribed overgrowth of the fibrous tissue.
A benign tumor composed of Schwann cells
tumor of the fibrous covering of a peripheral nerve

neurofibromatosis.explanation: A genetic disease characterized by multiple neurofibromas and pigmented spots on the skin, sometimes accompanied by bone deformity and a predisposition to cancers, especially of the brain.
The occurrence of one or more neurofibromata, or a general increase of fibrous tissue in the nerves.
A genetic disorder characterized by the presence of multiple neurofibromas under the skin
autosomal dominant disease characterized by numerous neurofibromas and by spots on the skin and often by developmental abnormalities

neurogenesis.explanation: The creation and development of neurons

neurogenetic.explanation: Of or pertaining to neurogenetics , the study of the genetic basis of nerve and brain function

neurogenic.explanation: Originating in the nerves or nervous tissue.
Caused or affected by the nerves or nervous system.
Originating in, or caused by, the nervous system
arising in or stimulated by nerve tissues

neuroglandular.explanation: neuroglandular pit of some Nemertini. Compare cerebral organ .

neuroglia.explanation: The supportive tissue of the nervous system, including the network of branched cells in the central nervous system (astrocytes, microglia, and oligodendrocytes) and the supporting cells of the peripheral nervous system (Schwann cells and satellite cells).
The peculiar sustentacular tissue of the cerebrospinal axis.

The delicate connective tissue framework which supports the nervous matter and blood vessels of the brain and spinal cord; called also Kölliker's reticulum . It is composed of cells which are not neurons. Once thought to serve merely a supporting funciton, they are now believed to have important metablolic functions. Among them are the astrocytes, ependymal cells, oligodendroglia cells, and microglia cells.
sustentacular tissue that surrounds and supports neurons in the central nervous system; glial and neural cells together compose the tissue of the central nervous system

neuroglial.explanation: Of or pertaining to the glial cells or neuroglia .
relating to or consisting of neuroglia

neuroglioma.explanation: A tumor formed of overgrowth of the neuroglia; a glioma.

neurography.explanation: Descriptive neurology; a description of or treatise on nerves.

neurohistology.explanation: The department of histology which treats of the minute structure of the nervous tissues and their elements, the neurones.

neurohormonal.explanation: Of or pertaining to a neurohormone .

neurohormone.explanation: A hormone secreted by or acting on a part of the nervous system.
Any hormone that stimulates the nervous system
a hormone that is released by nerve impulses (e.g., norepinephrine or vasopressin)

neurohumor.explanation: Any material produced in a neuron that activates a neighbouring neuron, muscle or gland ; a neurotransmitter

neurohumoral.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or produced by a neurohumor

neurohypnology.explanation: The means or process employed for inducing the hypnotic state. See hypnotism . Also neurypnology .

neurohypophysis.explanation: The posterior portion of the pituitary gland, having a rich supply of nerve fibers and releasing oxytocin and vasopressin.
The posterior lobe of the pituitary gland , responsible for the release of oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also called vasopressin .
the posterior lobe of the pituitary body; primarily glandular in nature

neuroid.explanation: One of the pair of distinct neural elements which compose the neural arch of a vertebra; a neurapophysis: correlated with pleuroid.
Resembling a nerve or similar neural structure; nervelike

neurokeratin.explanation: A substance, resembling keratin, present in nerve tissue, as in the sheath of the axis cylinder of medullated nerve fibers. Like keratin it resists the action of most chemical agents, and by decomposition with sulphuric acid yields leucin and tyrosin.
The protein component of the myelin sheath

neurolemma.explanation: the outermost nucleated cytoplasmic layer of Schwann cells that surrounds the axon of the neuron .
thin membranous sheath around a nerve fiber

neuroleptanalgesic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or inducing neuroleptanalgesia.

neuroleptic.explanation: An antipsychotic or anesthetic drug that causes apathy and decreased affect.
tranquilizer used to treat psychotic conditions when a calming effect is desired

neurolite.explanation: A soft yellow hydrated aluminium silicate occurring in fibrous masses, wood-like in aspect: from Stanstead, Province of Quebec.

neurologic.explanation: Relating to neurology or the nervous system .
of or relating to or used in or practicing neurology

neurological.explanation: Dealing with the study of the brain ; neurology .
of or relating to or used in or practicing neurology

neurologist.explanation: One who is versed in neurology.
One who is versed in neurology; also, one skilled in the treatment of nervous diseases.
A doctor or scientist who practices or specializes in neurology .
a medical specialist in the nervous system and the disorders affecting it

neurology.explanation: The branch of medicine that deals with the diagnosis and treatment of diseases and disorders of the nervous system.
Scientific knowledge or investigation of the form and functions of the nervous system in sickness and in health.
The branch of science which treats of the nervous system.
The branch of medicine that deals with the disorders of nervous system .
(neurology) the branch of medicine that deals with the nervous system and its disorders
the branch of medical science that deals with the nervous system

neurolysis.explanation: Destruction of nerve-substance; the physiological action of neurolysins.
The state of exhaustion in a nerve due to over-stimulation.

neuroma.explanation: A tumor composed of nerve tissue.
A tumor formed of nervous tissue.
A fibroma developed on a nerve.
A tumor developed on, or connected with, a nerve, esp. one consisting of new-formed nerve fibers.
A tumour composed of nerve cells
any tumor derived from cells of the nervous system

neuromalacia.explanation: Softening of nerves or nervous tissue.

neuromast.explanation: In zoology , a neuro-epithelial sense-organ, or modified epidermal tract, specialized as a sensitive surface or area.
A cluster of ciliated and other neural cells that serves as a simple sensory organ in some fish and amphibians

neuromastic.explanation: neuromastic canals, into which these structures may be withdrawn; neuromastic bones or scales, developed in connection with neuromasts.

neuromatous.explanation: of or relating to or caused by neuromas

neuromere.explanation: A segment or division of the neuron.
A metameric segment of the cerebro-spinal nervous system.
A morphologically or molecularly defined transient segment of the early developing brain .

neuromerism.explanation: The state or condition of metamerism, or segmentation in the central nervous system.

neuromimesis.explanation: Imitation in neurotic patients of organic disease; nervous mimicry.

neuromotor.explanation: Pertaining to the relationship between the nervous system and movement .
relating to a nerve fiber or impulse passing toward motor effectors

neuromuscular.explanation: Of, relating to, or affecting both nerves and muscles.
Having the characteristics of both nervous and muscular tissue.
neuromuscular cells of the freshwater polyp (Hydra).
Pertaining to the voluntary or reflexive control of muscles by nerves .
affecting or characteristic of both neural and muscular tissue

neuron.explanation: Any of the impulse-conducting cells that constitute the brain, spinal column, and nerves in vertebrates, consisting of a nucleated cell body with one or more dendrites and a single axon.
A similar impulse-conducting cell in invertebrates.
The cerebrospinal axis in its entirety; the whole of the encephalon and myelon, or brain and spinal cord, considered as one.
In entomology , a nervure of an insect's wing; a vein or costa.
The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis; myelencephalon.

The characteristic specialized cell that is part of the nervous system, serving to conduct electrical impulses to and from the brain, and also between other parts of the body, and composed of a main cell body, the axon, with a varying number of processes of varying length, the dendrites; a nerve cell. The movement and behavior of higher animals depends on the signals tranmsitted by such nerve cells.
A cell of the nervous system , which conducts nerve impulses ; consisting of an axon and several dendrites . Neurons are connected by synapses .
a cell that is specialized to conduct nerve impulses

neuronal.explanation: of, or relating to a neuron

neurone.explanation: One of the structural elements of the nervous system; a nerve-cell together with all its processes, the neuraxon and the dendrites.

neuronophagia.explanation: The destruction of nerve cells by phagocytes

neuronym.explanation: The anatomical name of a nerve.

neuroparalysis.explanation: Paralysis due to lesion of a nerve rather than to disease or destruction of the nervous centers.
paralysis because of damage to a nerve

neuropath.explanation: In pathology , one who assigns to the nervous system an excessive if not exclusive responsibility for disease.
A person of a nervous organization liable to or exhibiting nervous disease.

neuropathic.explanation: Of or pertaining to neuropathy; of the nature of, or suffering from, nervous disease.

neuropathist.explanation: One who is versed in the study and treatment of nervous diseases.

neuropathological.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or arising from neuropathology , the pathology of nerve tissue

neuropathologist.explanation: One who is skilled in neuropathology.

neuropathology.explanation: The scientific study of diseases of the nervous system.
The sum of human kNowledge concerning the diseases of the nervous system.
The pathology (diseases or study of diseases ) of the nervous system

neuropathy.explanation: A disease or abnormality of the nervous system.
In pathology , a general term for disease of the nervous system.
An affection of the nervous system or of a nerve.
Any disease of the peripheral nervous system .
any pathology of the peripheral nerves

neuropharmacologic.explanation: acting upon or influencing nervous functions; -- of chemical substances.

neuropharmacology.explanation: The study of the action of drugs on the nervous system.
A science concerned with drug -induced changes in the functioning of cells in the nervous system .

neurophysiologically.explanation: In terms of, or with regard to, neurophysiology .

neurophysiology.explanation: The branch of physiology that deals with the functions of the nervous system.
The branch of physiology that deals with the nervous system .
the branch of neuroscience that studies the physiology of the nervous system

neuropil.explanation: A fibrous network of nervous tissue that forms the gray matter of the brain
the complex network of unmyelinated axones, dendrites, and glial branches that form the bulk of the central nervous system's grey matter and in which nerve cell bodies are embedded

neuropile.explanation: One of the delicate, ultimate branches of a nerve-cell process.
the complex network of unmyelinated axones, dendrites, and glial branches that form the bulk of the central nervous system's grey matter and in which nerve cell bodies are embedded

neuroplasm.explanation: The protoplasm, or the living substance of the nerve-cells and their fibrillæ. Also called nerve-plasma .

neuroplasty.explanation: Surgical reunion of divided nerve-trunks and other forms of plastic surgery of the nerves.
Any surgery to repair nerve tissue.

neuropod.explanation: An invertebrate animal, as a worm, in which the neuropodia are well developed; an animal in which the limbs are upon the neural aspect of the body.

neuropodial.explanation: neuropodial cirrus or filament. See cuts under Polynoë, præstomium , and pygidium.

neuropodium.explanation: One of the series of ventral or inferior foot-stumps of a worm; one of the lower parapodia of an annelid; aventral oar: opposed to notopodium. See parapodium .
The ventral lobe or branch of a parapodium.
The ventral lobe or branch of a parapodium .

neuropodous.explanation: Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the neural side, as in most invertebrates; -- opposed to hæmapodous .

neuropore.explanation: An orifice of communication between the neural canal and the exterior in the embryos of some animals.
An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal.
An opening at either end of the embryonic neural canal .

neuropsychiatric.explanation: Of or pertaining to neuropsychiatry ; simultaneously neurological and psychiatric .

a mental or emotional disorder that affects only part of the personality, and involves less distorted perceptions of reality than a psychosis . The act of neutralizing; specifically, in chem. , the process by which an acid and a base are so combined that the resulting compound has neither acid nor basic properties.

An act of one or more nations imposing upon one of their number or upon another state a condition of permanent neutrality by ordaining that it shall not take part in any war into which the others may enter, in consideration for which its freedom from attack is usually guaranteed, as in the case of Switzerland in 1815, and Belgium since its separation from the Netherlands in 1830.

An act of military powers agreeing that certain persons, property, and places, such as surgeons, chaplains, and the wounded, medical supplies, hospitals, and ambulances, shall be deemed neutral in war, and not subject to capture, etc., as was agreed by the Geneva Convention, 1864.

More loosely, the act of securing by convention immunity for certain territory or waters from being made the scene of hostilities or of exclusive national maritime jurisdiction, as for the Black Sea, 1856, and for the Congo in Central Africa, 1885.
The condition of immunity and restriction resulting from any of such acts. Also spelled neutralisation .
The act or process of neutralizing, or the state of being neutralized.
The act or process by which an acid and a base are combined in such proportions that the resulting compound is neutral. See Neutral , a., 4.
(euphemism) the removal of a threat by killing or destroying it (especially in a covert operation or military operation)

New, Novel, Modern, Fresh, Recent, Late. In this connection new is opposed to old; novel to familiar; modern to ancient, medieval, antiquated, old-fashioned; fresh to stale; recent and late to early. New is the general word; that which is novel is unexpected, strange, striking, often in new form, but also pleasing: as, a novel combination of old ideas; that which is modern and fresh exists at the time referred tu; that which is recent or late is separated from the time of action by only a short interval: as, the late ministry, a recent arrival, recent times.

Synonyms News, Intelligence, Tidings, Advices. News is the most general word, applying to real information which is or is not important, interesting, or expected; news meets especially the desire to know. Intelligence is also a general word, applying to news or information of an interesting character, enabling one to understand better the situation of things in the place from which intelligence comes: as, intelligence from the Sandwich Islands to the 1st ult.; intelligence of a mutiny. Tidings are awaited with anxiety. Advices are items of information sent for the benefit or pleasure of those receiving them. Thus, Philip II. expected no intelligence from the Armada for some days after it sailed; soon rumor brought him false news of a glorious victory gained over the English: his first reliable news of the defeat of the Armada came through advices ; he received from time to time tidings of uniform disaster.

Nice., Dainty, Fastidious, Squeamish , finical, delicate, exquisite, effeminate, fussy. Nice is the most general of the first four words; it suggests careful choice: as, he is nice in his language and in his dress; it is rarely used of overwrought delicacy. Dainty is stronger than nice , and ranges from a commendable particularity to fastidiousness: as, to be dainty in one's choice of clothes or company; a dainty virtue. Fastidious almost always means a somewhat proud or haughty particularity; a fastidious person is hard to please, because he objects to minute points or to some point in almost everything. Squeamish is founded upon the notion of feeling nausea; hence it means fastidious to an extreme, absurdly particular.

An alkaloid which is the active principle of tobacco (C10H14N2). It occurs in tobacco plants ( Nicotiana tabacum and Nicotiana rusticum ) to the extent of 2 to 8%, in combination with malic acid or citric acid. It is a colorless, transparent, oily liquid, having an acrid odor, and an acrid burning taste. It is intensely poisonous. The apparently addictive effects of tobacco smoking have been ascribed largely to the effect of nicotine, and the controlled administration of nicotine on various forms has been used as a technique for assisting efforts to stop the smoking habit.
An alkaloid (C10H14N2), commonly occurring in the tobacco plant. In small doses it is a habit-forming stimulant ; in larger doses it is toxic and is often used in insecticides .

A design in black on a surface of silver, as that of a plaque, chalice, or any ornamental or useful object, formed by engraving the design and then filling up the incised furrows with an alloy composed of silver, copper, lead, crude sulphur, and borax, thus producing the effect of a black drawing on the bright surface. The process is of Italian origin, and is still extensively practised in Russia, where the finest niello is now produced. In many examples, conversely, the ground is cut out and inlaid with the black alloy, on which the design appears white or bright, as in the cut.

nighted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of night .

The close of the day; the arrival of the night; the period at and just after dusk.
The close of the day ; the coming of night .
the time of day immediately following sunset

nightgown.explanation: A loose garment worn in bed by women and girls.
A loose gown worn in one's chamber, at night or in the daytime; a dressing-gown; a robe de chambre; a negligée gown or house-dress, for either men or women.
A night-dress for women, high in the neck, with long sleeves, and covering the whole person.
A loose gown used for undress; also, a gown used for a sleeping garment.
A garment mainly worn by women for sleeping in.
lingerie consisting of a loose dress designed to be worn in bed by women

nighthawk.explanation: Any of several nightjars found throughout the Americas, having grayish-brown plumage that mimics leaves on the forest floor, especially Chordeiles minor.
One who prowls about at night; specifically, a night cabman or his cab or horse.
A caprimulgine bird of the genus Chordeiles.
The night-jar or goatsucker, Caprimulgus curopæus.
One of certain petrels of the genus Œstrelata : as, the white night-hawk or mutton-bird, Œ. lessoni.
A person who likes to be active late at night; a night owl .
Any of several mainly nocturnal North American goatsuckers, especially Chordeiles minor , or the related European goatsucker Caprimulgus europaeus , also called the nightjar.
A person whose preference or custom is to remain awake and active during the night and the early morning hours.
a person who likes to be active late at night

nightie.explanation: Any loose-fitting clothing for wear in bed.
a loose dress designed to be worn in bed by women; a nightgown.
A woman's nightgown or nightdress ; a dress -like garment worn to bed .
lingerie consisting of a loose dress designed to be worn in bed by women

nightingale.explanation: A songbird (Luscinia megarhynchos) of Eurasia and Africa with reddish-brown plumage, noted for the melodious song of the male during the breeding season, most often heard at night.
Any of various other songbirds of the genus Luscinia.
A sort of flannel scarf, with sleeves, designed to be worn by persons confined to bed. It was largely used by the sick and wounded in the Franco-German war, 1870–1.
A title popularly given to Jenny Lind, the famous Swedish singer.
A small sylviine bird of Europe, Asia, and Africa, belonging to the order Passeres , the suborder Oscines , the family Sylviidæ , and the genus Daulias.
Some bird which sings sweetly and hence is likened to or mistaken for a nightingale.
A small, plain, brown and gray European song bird ( Luscinia megarhynchos syn. Luscinia luscinia ). It sings at night, and is celebrated for the sweetness of its song.
A larger species ( Lucinia philomela ), of Eastern Europe, having similar habits; the thrush nightingale. The name is also applied to other allied species.
A European songbird , Luscinia megarhynchos, of the family Turdidae .
English nurse remembered for her work during the Crimean War (1820-1910)
European songbird noted for its melodious nocturnal song

nightish.explanation: Of or pertaining to night ; nocturnal .

nightjar.explanation: Any of various chiefly nocturnal, insectivorous birds of the family Caprimulgidae, especially those in the genus Caprimulgus.
A bird, Caprimulgus europæus , of the family Caprimulgidæ.
A goatsucker, esp. the European species. See Illust. of goatsucker .
Any of various medium-sized nocturnal birds of the family Caprimulgidae , that feed predominantly on moths and other large flying insects .
mainly crepuscular or nocturnal nonpasserine birds with mottled greyish-brown plumage and large eyes; feed on insects

nightless.explanation: nightless period in the arctic regions.

nightlife.explanation: Social activities or entertainment available or pursued in the evening.
the activity of people seeking nighttime diversion (as at the theater, a nightclub, etc.)
the entertainment available to people seeking nighttime diversion

nightlike.explanation: Resembling night or some aspect of it; dark , tenebrous .

nightlong.explanation: Lasting a night (i.e. the duration of one night); lasting all night.
lasting, open, or operating through the whole night

nightly.explanation: Of or occurring during the night; nocturnal.

Nightly, Nocturnal. The former is the more familiar. Nightly tends to limitation to that which occurs every night (see definition 2), while nocturnal tends to cover both that which belongs to the night, as nocturnal insects, flowers, vision, and that which exists or occurs, however accidentally, in the night, as a nocturnal ramble.
Of or pertaining to the night, or to every night; happening or done by night, or every night
Happening or appearing in the night; night-time ; nocturnal .
Performing, occurring, or taking place every night .
A build of a software program with the latest changes, released every night .
at the end of each day

nightman.explanation: One who is on duty at night, as a watchman.
A scavenger whose business is the cleaning of ash-pits and privies in the night.
One whose business is emptying privies by night.
One whose business is emptying privies by night .

nightmare.explanation: A dream arousing feelings of intense fear, horror, and distress.
An event or experience that is intensely distressing.
A demon or spirit once thought to plague sleeping people.
An incubus or evil spirit that oppresses people during sleep.

An oppressed state during sleep, accompanied by a feeling of intense fear, horror, or anxiety, or of inability to escape from some threatened danger or from pursuing phantoms or monsters. Also called incubus .
Any overpowering, oppressive, or stupefying influence.
A fiend or incubus formerly supposed to cause trouble in sleep.

A trerrifying or oppressive dream characterized by a sense of helplessness in the face of danger, extreme uneasiness or discomfort (as of weight on the chest or stomach, impossibility of motion or speech, etc.) or extreme anxiety, from which one wakes in a troubled state of mind.
Any overwhelming, oppressive, or terrifying experience resembling a nightmare{2} especially in the inability to escape from an unpleasant situation.
A female demon or monster, thought to plague people while they slept and cause a feeling of suffocation and terror during sleep.
A very bad or frightening dream .
Any bad , miserable , difficult or terrifying situation or experience that arouses anxiety , terror , agony or great displeasure .
a situation resembling a terrifying dream
a terrifying or deeply upsetting dream

nightmarish.explanation: Terrifying, as if in a nightmare{2}; resembling a nightmare{2}.

nightmarishness.explanation: The state or condition of being nightmarish .

nightrider.explanation: One of a secret band of mounted, usually masked white men who engaged in nocturnal terrorism for revenge or intimidation in the southern United States especially during Reconstruction.
One who rides by night; specifically, a member of a band of (usually mounted) men who perpetrate deeds of violence or intimidation by night.
member of a secret mounted band in the southern U. S. after the Civil War, which committed acts of intimidation and revenge.
member of a secret mounted band in United States South after the American Civil War; committed acts of intimidation and revenge
member of a secret mounted band in United States South after the American Civil War; committed acts of intimidation and revenge

nights.explanation: During the nighttime on every day or most days.

nightshade.explanation: A plant of the nightshade family, especially a poisonous one of the genus Solanum or Atropa, such as bittersweet nightshade or belladonna.
Solanum aculeatisdmum , a shrubby and prickly species with yellow berries found from North Carolina to Florida and west to Texas.
A plant of the genus Solanum , or of the Solanaceæ or nightshade family.
The name of a few plants of other orders, as below.
A common name of many species of the genus Solanum, given esp. to the Solanum nigrum , or black nightshade, a low, branching weed with small white flowers and black berries reputed to be poisonous.
Any of the poisonous plants belonging to the genus Solanum , especially black nightshade or woody nightshade .
Any plant of the wider Solanaceae family, including the nightshades as well as tomato , potato , eggplant , and deadly nightshade .
Belladonna or deadly nightshade , Atropa belladonna.
Any of several plants likened to nightshade, usually because of similar dark-colored berries.
any of numerous shrubs or herbs or vines of the genus Solanum; most are poisonous though many bear edible fruit

nightshirt.explanation: A long, loose shirt worn in bed.
A plain loose shirt for sleeping in.
A kind of nightgown for men.
A shirt -like garment (often oversized ) that is worn to bed .

nightside.explanation: The side of a planet that faces away from the sun around which it orbits

nightspot.explanation: An establishment that is open late at night , especially one that provides entertainment, such as a nightclub
a spot that is open late at night and that provides entertainment (as singers or dancers) as well as dancing and food and drink

nightstick.explanation: A club carried by a police officer.
A strong club carried by a policeman at night.
A long narrow pole-like club carried by police and security people, for use in self-defense. Often shortened to stick .
a short stout club used primarily by policemen

nightstool.explanation: A chamber pot built into a chair .

nighttime.explanation: The time between sunset and sunrise.
Occurring in or appropriate for use during the night.
The time from dusk to dawn; -- opposed to daytime .
The hours of darkness between sunset and sunrise ; the night .
the time after sunset and before sunrise while it is dark outside

nightwalker.explanation: One, especially a robber or prostitute, who walks the streets at night.
terrestrial worm that burrows into and helps aerate soil; often surfaces when the ground is cool or wet; used as bait by anglers

nightwear.explanation: garments designed to be worn in bed

nightwork.explanation: work to be done at night

nighty.explanation: A night-gown or night-dress: originally a child's word.
Good night Abbreviation of nighty night ..

nignay.explanation: A trifle; a trifling thing or act.

nigori.explanation: The substitution of an impure consonantal sound for a pure one when it begins the second part of a compound, or the second part of a plural expression formed by reduplication, as in kami-dana (which see) for kami-tana , ‘god-shelf’; kawa-guchi for kawa-kuchi , ‘river-mouth’; ban-zai (which see) for ban-sai , ‘ten thousand years’; kanagawa for kana-kawa (name of the prefecture in which Yokohama is situated); hito-bito , ‘men,’ for hito-hito , from hito , ‘man,’ etc.
In Japanese writing and printing, the mark (earlier ), placed at the right of a pure consonant to show that it has become impure.

nigraniline.explanation: An intermediate product of the oxidation of aniline to aniline black (which see, under black ).
The complex, nitrogenous, organic base and dyestuff called also aniline black .
A complex , nitrogenous , organic base and black dyestuff .

nigrescence.explanation: The process of becoming black or dark.
Blackness or darkness, as of complexion.
The process of becoming black or dark; blackening .

nigrescent.explanation: Growing black; changing to a black color; approaching to blackness.
Growing or becoming black ; approaching blackness.

nigrification.explanation: The act or process of making black.
The act or process of making black .

nigritian.explanation: An inhabitant of Nigritia; hence, a negro.

nigritude.explanation: Blackness; the state of being black.
blackness ; the state of being black

nigrosine.explanation: Any of a class of dyes, varying from blue to black, used in the manufacture of inks and for dyeing wood and textiles.
A coal-tar color used in dyeing, prepared from the hydrochlorid of violaniline.
The name is applied to three different coal-tar colors:
Spirit-soluble nigrosine, which is closely allied to spirit-soluble induliue.
Water-soluble nigrosine, which is the sodium salt of certain snlphonic acids of spirit-soluble nigrosine.
A dark blue dyestuff, of the induline group; -- called also azodiphenyl blue .
A dark blue synthetic dyestuff of the induline group.

nigua.explanation: In Cuba and Porto Rico, a name applied to several plants belonging to the genus Tournefortia of the borage family, especially to T. hirsutissima , a trailing shrub with one-sided spikes of flowers resembling those of heliotrope.

nihil.explanation: the general issue in certain actions of debt.
a declinature by the defendant to plead or answer.
(Latin) nil; nothing (as used by a sheriff after an unsuccessful effort to serve a writ)

nihilianism.explanation: A name given by the opponents of Peter Lombard to his view that the divine nature did not undergo any change in the incarnation, and that therefore Christ did not become human.

nihilism.explanation: The doctrine that nothing actually exists or that existence or values are meaningless.
Relentless negativity or cynicism suggesting an absence of values or beliefs.
Political belief or action that advocates or commits violence or terrorism without discernible constructive goals.

A diffuse, revolutionary movement of mid-19th-century Russia that scorned authority and tradition and believed in reason, materialism, and radical change in society and government through terrorism and assassination.
A delusion, experienced in some mental disorders, that the world or one's mind, body, or self does not exist.
In metaphysics , the doctrine that nothing can really be known, because nothing exists; the denial of all real existence, and consequently of all knowledge of existences or real things.
In theology , same as nihilianism .
Total disbelief in religion, morality, law, and order.

Originally, a social (not a political) movement in Russia, in opposition to the customary forms of matrimony, the parental authority, and the tyranny of custom. In this sense the word was introduced by Turgeneff in 1862. See nihilist , 3.
Later, a more or less organized secret effort on the part of a large body of malcontents to overturn the established order of things, both social and political.
Nothingness; nihility.
The doctrine that nothing can be known; scepticism as to all knowledge and all reality.
The theories and practices of the Nihilists.
Extreme skepticism , maintaining that nothing has a real existence.
The rejection of all moral principles .

(capitalized by protagonist Turgenev) A Russian anarchistic revolutionary doctrine (1860-1917) holding that conditions in the social organization are so bad as to make destruction desirable for its own sake, independent of any constructive program or possibility.
The belief that all endeavors are ultimately futile and devoid of meaning.
Contradiction (not always deliberate) between behavior and espoused principle, to such a degree that all possible espoused principle is voided.
The deliberate refusal of belief , to the point that belief itself is rejected as untenable.
the delusion that things (or everything, including the self) do not exist; a sense that everything is unreal
a revolutionary doctrine that advocates destruction of the social system for its own sake
complete denial of all established authority and institutions

nihilist.explanation: One who believes in nothing; one who advocates the metaphysical doctrine of nihilism.
One who rejects all the positive beliefs upon which existing society and governments are founded; one who demands the abolition of the existing social and political order of things.

Specifically An adherent of nihilism; a member of a Russian secret society which aims at the overthrow of the existing order of things, social, political, and religious; a Russian anarchist or revolutionary reformer. See nihilism , 4.
One who advocates the doctrine of nihilism; one who believes or teaches that nothing can be known, or asserted to exist.
A member of a secret association (esp. in Russia), which is devoted to the destruction of the present political, religious, and social institutions.
A person who accepts or champions nihilism .
An absolute skeptic ; a person who believes in the truth of nothing.
someone who rejects all theories of morality or religious belief

nihilistic.explanation: Of, pertaining to, or characterized by, nihilism.

nihility.explanation: The state of being nothing, or of no account or importance; nothingness.
Nothingness; a state of being nothing.

nikau.explanation: In New Zealand, Hedyscepe sapida , a palm-tree with a slender green ringed stem and pinnate leaves with narrow linear leaflets. The young unexpanded inflorescence is eaten by the natives. This species occurs also on the Chatham islands and is the most southerly representative of the palm family.

nikethamide.explanation: A stimulant which mainly affects the respiratory cycle .

nil.explanation: In musical acoustics , a minute interval, equal to a fifty-first part of a semitone.
A special value for a variable used in certain computer languages to mean no assigned value, to be distinguished from the value zero.

nilgai.explanation: A large brown or bluish-gray antelope (Boselaphus tragocamelus) native to India, Nepal, and Pakistan, the male of which has short, sturdy horns and strands of long hair hanging down from the throat.
Same as nilgau : the form most commonly used in India to designate the large antelope Portax pictus.
A large antelope , of the genus Boselaphus , from northern India ; the blue bull
large Indian antelope; male is blue-grey with white markings; female is brownish with no horns

nilgau.explanation: A large Indian antelope, Portax pictus , related to the addax and the oryx, of a bluish-gray color, with short little-curved horns, a blackish mane, and a bunch of hair on the throat.

nill.explanation: Not to will; not to wish.
The shining sparks of brass given off in trying and melting the ore.
Scales of hot iron from the forge.
To be unwilling; to refuse to act.
whether he wills it or not; usually contracted to willy-nilly .
Not to will; to refuse; to reject.
Shining sparks thrown off from melted brass.
Scales of hot iron from the forge.
Shining sparks thrown off from melted brass.
Scales of hot iron from the forge.
To be unwilling; will not (+ infinitive).

nilometer.explanation: A gage or measure of depth or height of the flow of the river Nile.
Hence, any instrument for making a continuous and automatic register of riverheights.
An instrument for measuring the rise of water in the Nile during its periodical flood.
a device used to measure the rise of water in the Nile at the flood

nilot.explanation: One who dwells on the banks of the Nile.

nilpotent.explanation: An algebraic quantity that when raised to a certain power equals zero.
mathematics , vanishing on being raised to a certain power. Thus, if i be such an expression in multiple algebra that i × i × i = 0, i is nilpotent
Describing an element , of a ring , for which there exists some positive integer n such that xn = 0.
equal to zero when raised to a certain power

nim.explanation: A game in which players in turn remove small objects from a collection, such as matchsticks arranged in rows, and attempt to take, or avoid taking, the last one.
The margosa. See Melia . Also spelled neem .
To take; to steal; to filch.
To take (in all senses); to seize .
To take one's way; to go .
To walk with short, quick strides; trip along.
A game in which players take turns removing objects from heaps .

game in which matchsticks are arranged in rows and players alternately remove one or more of them; in some versions the object is to take the last remaining matchstick on the table and in other versions the object is to avoid taking the last remaining matchstick on the table

nimbiferous.explanation: Serving to bring clouds or stormy weather.
Serving to bring clouds or stormy weather .

nimble.explanation: Quick, light, or agile in movement or action; deft.
Quick, clever, and acute in devising or understanding: synonym : dexterous .

Light, brisk, expeditious, speedy, spry; Nimble, Agile. The last two words express lightness and quickness in motion, the former being more suggestive of the use of the feet, the latter of that of the whole lower limbs.
Light and quick in motion; moving with ease and celerity; lively; swift.
a slender, branching, American grass ( Muhlenbergia diffusa ), of some repute for grazing purposes in the Mississippi valley.
Quick and light in movement or action.

nimbleness.explanation: The quality of being nimble; lightness and agility in motion; quickness; celerity; speed; swiftness.
The quality of being nimble; lightness and quickness in motion; agility; swiftness.
the gracefulness of a person or animal that is quick and nimble
intelligence as revealed by quickness and alertness of mind

nimbler.explanation: comparative form of nimble : more nimble

nimblest.explanation: superlative form of nimble : most nimble .

nimbly.explanation: In a nimble manner; with agility; with light, quick motion.
in a nimble or agile manner; with quickness and lightness and ease

nimbostratus.explanation: A low, gray, often dark cloud that precipitates rain, snow, or sleet.
A low-level, principal cloud type, generally formless and dark grey in colour, occurring in layers at low altitude (usually below 2400 metres ) and usually bringing precipitation; abbreviated Ns.

nimbus.explanation: A cloudy radiance said to surround a classical deity when on earth.
A radiant light that appears usually in the form of a circle or halo about or over the head in the representation of a god, demigod, saint, or sacred person such as a king or an emperor.
A splendid atmosphere or aura, as of glamour, that surrounds a person or thing.
A rain cloud, especially a low dark layer of clouds such as a nimbostratus.
A cloud or system of clouds from which rain is falling; a rain-cloud. See cloud .

In art and Christian archæol. , a halo or disk of light surrounding the head in representations of divine or sacred personages; also, a disk or circle sometimes depicted in early times round the heads of emperors and other great men.
In heraldry , a circle formed of a single line, drawn around the head and disappearing where it seems to go behind it.
A circle, or disk, or any indication of radiant light around the heads of divinities, saints, and sovereigns, upon medals, pictures, etc.; a halo. See aureola , and glory , n., 5.
A rain cloud; one of the four principal varieties of clouds. See Cloud .
A circle of light ; a halo .
an indication of radiant light drawn around the head of a saint
a dark grey cloud bearing rain

nimiety.explanation: The state of being too much; redundancy; excess.
state of being in excess , possessing more than is needed
a quantity much larger than is needed

nimrod.explanation: A person regarded as silly, foolish, or stupid.
A silly or foolish person; An idiot .

nina.explanation: A goddess of the watery deep and daughter of Ea.
the Babylonian goddess of the watery deep and daughter of Ea

nincompoop.explanation: A silly, foolish, or stupid person.
A fool; a blockhead; a simpleton.
A fool; a silly or stupid person.

nincompoopery.explanation: The beliefs and behaviours of a nincompoop ; folly ; idiocy .

nine.explanation: The cardinal number equal to 8 + 1.
The ninth in a set or sequence.
Something having nine parts, units, or members.
A playing card marked with nine pips.
A set of nine persons or things, especially.
The nine players on a side, or the whole team.
The nine Muses.
A size, as in clothing or shoes, designated as nine.
The first or second 9 holes of an 18-hole golf course.
( to the nines ) To the highest degree.
The number consisting of the sum of one and eight; the number less by unity than ten; three times three.
A symbol representing nine units, as 9, or IX, or ix.
The body of players, nine in number, composing one side in a game of base-ball.
A playing-card with nine spots or pips on it.
Eight and one more; one less than ten.
See Morris .

a circle so related to any given triangle as to pass through the three points in which the perpendiculars from the angles of the triangle upon the opposite sides (or the sides produced) meet the sides. It also passes through the three middle points of the sides of the triangle and through the three middle points of those parts of the perpendiculars that are between their common point of meeting and the angles of the triangle. The circle is hence called the nine points circle or six points circle .
The number greater than eight by a unit; nine units or objects.
A symbol representing nine units, as 9 or ix.
A group of nine people.
the nine Muses.
A numerical value equal to 9 ; the number occurring after eight and before ten .
Describing a set or group with nine components.
The digit or figure 9 .
A playing card with nine pips .
A nine-millimeter semi-automatic pistol .
A statistical unit of proportion (of reliability , purity , etc.).
one of four playing cards in a deck with nine pips on the face
the cardinal number that is the sum of eight and one
a team of professional baseball players who play and travel together
denoting a quantity consisting of one more than eight and one less than ten

ninebark.explanation: Any of several shrubs of the genus Physocarpus of the rose family, especially P. opulifolius of eastern North America, having peeling or shredding bark and clusters of small white flowers.
Any flowering plant of the genus Physocarpus.

ninefold.explanation: ninefold seems to be used elliptically for ninefold offspring or ninefold company:
having nine times as much or as many

nineholes.explanation: A game in which nine holes are made in a board or the ground, at which the players roll small balls.
A game in which nine holes are made in the ground, into which a ball is bowled.
An old game where players bowl a ball towards nine holes in the ground, scoring points according to which hole the ball enters.

ninepence.explanation: In New England, a Spanish silver coin, the real (of Mexican plate), about equal in value to 9 pence of New England currency, or 12½ cents. The word is still occasionally used in reckoning.
An old English silver coin, worth nine pence.
A New England name for the Spanish real, a coin formerly current in the United States, as valued at twelve and a half cents.
A former British silver coin , worth nine old pennies .
A Spanish real , valued at twelve and a half cents .

ninepenny.explanation: 2-3/4 in or 7 cm long; -- used of nail size.
Having a value or cost of ninepence .
used of nail size; 2 3/4 in or 7 cm long

ninepin.explanation: A bowling game in which nine wooden pins are the target.
A wooden pin used in the game of ninepins.
a bowling pin of the type used in ninepins (or (in England) skittles).
The wooden pin used in the game of ninepins ; a skittle
a bowling pin of the type used in playing ninepins or (in England) skittles

ninepins.explanation: The game of bowls played in an alley with nine men or pins.
plural The pins with which this game is played. See tenpins .
A game played with nine pins, or pieces of wood, set on end, at which a wooden ball is bowled to knock them down; bowling.
a bowling game that is played by rolling a bowling ball down a bowling alley at a target of nine wooden pins

ninescore.explanation: Nine times twenty, or one hundred and eighty.

nineteen.explanation: The 19th in a set or sequence.
A number equal to the sum of nine and ten, or one less than twenty.
A symbol representing nineteen units, as 19, or XIX, or xix.
Nine and ten; eighteen and one more; one less than twenty.
The number greater than eighteen by a unit; the sum of ten and nine; nineteen units or objects.
A symbol for nineteen units, as 19 or xix.
The cardinal number occurring after eighteen and before twenty, represented in Roman numerals as XIX and in Arabic numerals as 19. It is the last/largest of the " teens ".
the cardinal number that is the sum of eighteen and one

nineteenth.explanation: The ordinal number matching the number 19 in a series.
A nineteenth part; the quotient of unity divided by nineteen.
In music , the interval, whether melodic or harmonic, between any tone and a tone two octaves and a fifth distant from it; also, a tone distant by such an interval from a given tone.
In organ-building , a stop whose pitch is two octaves and a fifth above that of the keys used, as, for example, the larigot.
Following the eighteenth and preceding the twentieth; coming after eighteen others.
Constituting or being one of nineteen equal parts into which anything is divided.
The quotient of a unit divided by nineteen; one of nineteen equal parts of anything.
The next in order after the eighteenth.
An interval of two octaves and a fifth.
The ordinal form of the number nineteen .
The person or thing in the nineteenth position.
One of nineteen equal parts of a whole.
position 19 in a countable series of things
coming next after the eighteenth in position

nineteenthly.explanation: In nineteenth place; nineteenth in a row.

nineties.explanation: The time of life between ages 90 and 100.
The decade of one's life from age 90 through age 99.
the time of life between 90 and 100

ninetieth.explanation: The ordinal number matching the number 90 in a series.
A ninetieth part; the quotient of unity divided by ninety: as, two ninetieths.
Next in order after the eighty-ninth.
Constituting or being one of ninety equal parts.
The quotient of a unit divided by ninety; one of ninety equal parts of anything.
The next in order after the eighty-ninth.
The ordinal form of the number ninety .
The person or thing in the ninetieth position.
One of ninety equal parts of a whole.
position 90 in a countable series of things
the ordinal number of ninety in counting order

ninety.explanation: A decade or the numbers from 90 to 99.
The decade from 90 to 99 in a century.
The sum of ten nines, or nine tens; nine times ten.
A symbol representing ninety units, as 90, or XC, or xc.
Nine times ten; eighty-nine and one more.
The sum of nine times ten; the number greater by a unit than eighty-nine; ninety units or objects.
A symbol representing ninety units, as 90 or xc.
The cardinal number occurring after eighty-nine and before ninety-one , represented in Roman numerals as XC and in Arabic numerals as 90 .
the cardinal number that is the product of ten and nine

ninetyish.explanation: Of about ninety years of age.

ninevite.explanation: An inhabitant of Nineveh, the ancient capital of Assyria.

ningle.explanation: A familiar friend, whether male or female; a favorite or friend. See ingle .
In a bad sense, a male paramour.

ninhydrin.explanation: The aromatic compound 2,2-dihydroxyindane-1,3-dione which is used as a reagent to detect amines

ninja.explanation: A member of a class of medieval Japanese mercenary agents who were trained in the martial arts and hired for covert operations such as assassination and sabotage.
A person trained primarily in stealth , espionage , assassination and the Japanese martial art of ninjutsu .
A Mongolian amateurish private miner (mainly for gold); after the shape of the plastic bowls used to wash metal ore with mercury , roughly resembling one of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
Juggalo version of the epithet " nigga ".
To act in the manner of a ninja, especially in the areas of speed and power.
To claim an item in a game by abusing game mechanics, often despite having no real need for the item or ability to use it.

off.

unless before; -- a phrase applied to terms of court, held generally by a single judge, with a jury, for the trial of civil causes. The term originated in a legal fiction. An issue of fact being made up, it is, according to the English practice, appointed by the entry on the record, or written proceedings, to be tried by a jury from the county of which the proceedings are dated, at Westminster, unless before the day appointed ( nisi prius ) the judges shall have come to the county in question (which they always do) and there try the cause. See In banc, under Banc .

nispero.explanation: In Spain, the medlar-tree, Mespilus Germanica.

niter.explanation: The word niter (in its Hebrew, Greek, and Latin forms) was used in early times to signify any kind of saline efflorescence, and therefore included a number of substances now recognized as distinct. The ‘niter’ of the Old Testament scriptures was obviously natron in the sense of naturally occurring carbonate of soda (from Egypt). The ‘nitrum’ mentioned by Pliny, which gave off a strong smell on being sprinkled with lime, must have been a salt of ammonium, probably the chlorid; but potassium nitrate (the niter or saltpeter of the present age), and also calcium nitrate, potassium carbonate, sodium chlorid, magnesium sulphate, and the sulphates of zinc, iron, and copper (later distinguished as metallic vitriols) were probably more or less confounded under the general name.
A salt (KNO 3 ), also called saltpeter , and in the nomenclature of chemistry potassium nitrate.
A white crystalline semitransparent salt; potassium nitrate; saltpeter. See saltpeter .
a deliquescent salt, sodium nitrate, found as a native incrustation, like niter, in Peru and Chile, whence it is known also as Chile saltpeter .
a genus (Nitraria) of thorny shrubs bearing edible berries, and growing in the saline plains of Asia and Northern Africa.
A mineral form of potassium nitrate used in making gunpowder .
(KNO3) used especially as a fertilizer and explosive

They are prepared by the action of alkyl haloids on potassium cyanide and, in some cases, by the dehydration of organic ammonium salts into which they are reconverted by the action of acids or alkalies. They are also called acid nitriles or alkyl cyanides. Occasionally tertiary amines (R 3 N) are called nitrile bases .

the univalent radical -NO2, and the anion NO2-

nitro.explanation: An element in some compounds, meaning ‘niter,’ and usually implying ‘nitrogen’ or ‘nitric acid’; specifically, as a prefix in chemical words, indicating the presence of the radical nitryl (NO 2 ) in certain compounds: as, nitro -aniline, nitr anisic acid, nitro -benzamide, nitro -benzoic acid.

It is also employed, very commonly but in regard to technical use incorrectly, as a part of the name of a compound which does not contain the radical nitryl (NO 2 ) with its nitrogen directly united to carbon. Thus nitroglycerin and nitrocellulose (guncotton) are not nitro-compounds in the technical sense of the term, but nitrates.
containing the nitro group; such compounds tend to be unstable and often explosive

soil bacteria that convert nitrites to nitrates

It is used in perfumery, and is manufactured in large quantities in the preparation of aniline. Fornerly called also nitrobenzol .

A cotton -like material, made from cellulose by the action of nitric and sulphuric acids , used in the manufacture of explosives , collodion etc.
a nitric acid ester; used in lacquers and explosives

A nitro derivative of methane, analogous to chloroform, obtained as a colorless oily or crystalline substance, CH.(NO2)3, quite explosive, and having well-defined acid properties.
The explosive nitro compound CH(NO2)3, analagous to chloroform ; trinitromethane

derivative of furan used to inhibit bacterial growth

nitrogelatin.explanation: An explosive consisting largely of nitroglycerin with smaller proportions of guncotton and camphor.

This important explosive has no relation in chemical composition to gelatin. The name has reference merely to its jelly-like consistence. Its value depends in large measure upon the fact that of its two principal components the one, guncotton, contains an insufficient proportion of oxygen for complete combustion, while the other, nitroglycerin, contains an excess of the same element; by blending proper quantities of the two, complete oxidation of the carbon and hydrogen is effected, with consequent maximum evolution of energy.
An explosive consisting of gun cotton and camphor dissolved in nitroglycerin.
An explosive consisting of guncotton and camphor dissolved in nitroglycerin .

nitrogen.explanation: A nonmetallic element that constitutes nearly four-fifths of the air by volume, occurring as a colorless, odorless, almost inert diatomic gas, N 2 , in various minerals and in all proteins and used in a wide variety of applications, including manufacture of ammonia, nitric acid, TNT, and fertilizers, and as a cryogen. Atomic number 7; atomic weight 14.0067; melting point −210.00°C; boiling point −195.80°C; valence 2, 3, 4, 5. cross-reference : Periodic Table .
The boiling-point of liquid nitrogen under ordinary atmospheric pressure is -194.4° C. or -317.9° F. For the fixation of atmospheric nitrogen by growing plants, see nitragin .
Chemical symbol, N; atomic weight, 14. An element existing in nature as a colorless, odorless, tasteless gas, reducible to a liquid under extreme pressure and cold.

A colorless nonmetallic element of atomic number 7, tasteless and odorless, comprising four fifths of the atmosphere by volume in the form of molecular nitrogen (N2). It is chemically very inert in the free state, and as such is incapable of supporting life (hence the name azote still used by French chemists); but it forms many important compounds, such as ammonia, nitric acid, the cyanides, etc, and is a constituent of all organized living tissues, animal or vegetable. Symbol N. Atomic weight 14.007. It was formerly regarded as a permanent noncondensible gas, but was liquefied in 1877 by Cailletet of Paris, and Pictet of Geneva, and boils at -195.8 ° C at atmospheric pressure. Liquid nitrogen is used as a refrigerant to store delicate materials, such as bacteria, cells, and other biological materials.
A chemical element (symbol N) with an atomic number of 7 and atomic weight of 14.0067.
Molecular nitrogen (N2), a colorless , odorless gas at room temperature.
A specific nitrogen within a chemical formula, or a specific isotope of nitrogen
a common nonmetallic element that is normally a colorless odorless tasteless inert diatomic gas; constitutes 78 percent of the atmosphere by volume; a constituent of all living tissues

nitrogenization.explanation: The act or process of nitrogenizing, or impregnating with nitrogen; impregnation or inoculation with nitrogen; nitrification.
